{"sim": 0.8823529481887817, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9785310", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "title": "USA Today", "id": "335"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/f5c8b76111a34e9e28ae3749eea7e41ae0fdc10d/c=0-298-5851-3604&r=x803&c=1600x800/local/-/media/2017/08/17/USATODAY/USATODAY/636385835500656701-GTY-813430400-92328741.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 469, "textEnd": 476, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/08/17/commander-stricken-destroyer-fitzgerald-relieved-after-navy-report-cites-failures/577805001/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:08:00", "title": "Commander of stricken destroyer Fitzgerald relieved after Navy report cites failures", "uri": "711137479", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:08:00Z", "time": "22:08:00", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nWASHINGTON -- The head of the Navy's 7th Fleet has relieved the skipper of the USS Fitzgerald and two other officers for losing \"situational awareness\" in the hours leading up to a fatal June collision that left seven sailors dead, the service's deputy chief said Thursday.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, the deputy chief of naval operations, said that Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin relieved Cmdr. Bryce Benson for cause after a report detailing the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and the freighter ACX Crystal was released by the Navy.\n\nThe ship's entire leadership, Moran said, will be relieved, and about a dozen sailors face punishment, including all of the destroyer's watch.\n\nThe command team of three have been relieved. About nine others face non-judicial punishment.\n\nFurther sanctions are possible, Moran said.\n\nAucoin acted swiftly because the investigation indicated serious mistakes were made by the crew, Moran said. The Navy has lost confidence in those sailors.\n\nCollisions should never happen, Moran said. \"We got it wrong.\"\n\nA \"loud noise\" roused some of the sailors in the Fitzgerald's Berthing 2 compartment, the accident report said. Some in the ship's sleeping and living quarters \"felt an unusual movement,\" while others slept through the initial crash.\n\nSeconds after the ACX Crystal plowed into the starboard side of the Navy's guided missile destroyer at 1:30 a.m., on June 17, seawater gushed through a 13-foot-by-17-foot gash, knocking some from their beds and threatening to drown all 35 sailors in the compartment.\n\n\"Water on deck!\" sailors shouted. \"Get out!\"\n\nThe harrowing moments and hours after the collision -- and the heroism that saved the lives of all but seven of the 35 sailors in Berthing 2 -- are recounted in the report.\n\nIt details the frantic efforts to account for all the sailors in the darkened, flooding compartment, keep the ship afloat, and rescue the ship's commander who dangled outside his crumpled cabin.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dark of night to save their ship,\" wrote Rear Adm. C.F. Williams, commander of Carrier Strike Group Five. Williams' preliminary report looks at the injuries and deaths that resulted from the crash.\n\nThe Fitzgerald, with a crew of about 300 sailors, was about 56 nautical miles southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, at the time of the collision. The sea was calm, and the moon shone through broken clouds. The ship was dark but for navigation lights, and red bulbs inside.\n\nThe Crystal is a far larger ship at 728 feet and 29,000 tons, compared with the Fitzgerald's 505 feet and 9,000 tons. The port side of the Crystal's bow slammed into the Fitzgerald above the waterline, and the bulb-like bow below the surface crunched into the Fitzgerald near Berthing 2.\n\nFlooding in Berthing 2\n\nBerthing 2 held 42 beds in stacks of three bunks, a bathroom, and a lounge area. It contained a lounge with sofas, chairs and a television. After the collision, \"nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald rocked violently, settling into a 7-degree list to her starboard side.\n\n\"One sailor saw another knocked out of his rack by water,\" according to the report. \"Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up.\"\n\nWithin a minute, the compartment had flooded and the water rose. Mattresses, furniture and an exercise bike floated in the aisles. The tilting ship complicated the escape, and the water was neck high by the time many had reached the ladder to climb to safety.\n\nAs the water forced them to the top of the stairs, two sailors reached into the dark water and fished two more shipmates out. The last rescued sailor had been in the bathroom at the time of the crash. The sailors \"pulled him from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported he was taking is final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nThe seven sailors who drowned were nearest the gash, \"directly in the path of the onrushing water.\"\n\nMore: Navy releases names of sailors killed in USS Fitzgerald collision\n\nMore: Navy collisions rare but provide lessons in their wake\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORERead or Share this story: https://usat.ly/2x8KuqB", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Water_Resources", "wgt": 100, {"sim": 0.8705882430076599, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9808721", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "title": "yahoo.com", "id": "228"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/2.ggGSgKlKcTe17dBNPMXA--/aD0xOTg5O3c9MzAwMDtzbT0xO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/ap_webfeeds/250b20b986de4374901ae70548632ced.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 16, "textEnd": 29, "date": "2017-06-17", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 411, "textEnd": 418, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2562, "textEnd": 2569, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/senior-officer-damaged-ship-relieved-command-222253522--politics.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:07:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged ship to be relieved of command", "uri": "711208163", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:07:00Z", "time": "02:07:00", "body": "1 / 2FILE- This June 17, 2017 file photo shows the damaged USS Fitzgerald near the U.S. Naval base in Yokosuka, southwest of Tokyo. The Navy says the commanding officer of a warship that lost seven sailors in a collision off the coast of Japan will be relieved of command, and nearly a dozen other sailors face punishment. Adm. William Moran, the No. 2 Navy officer, told reporters at the Pentagon on Thursday, Aug. 17, that the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed. (AP Photo/Eugene Hoshiko, File)\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe damaged USS Fitzgerald sits near the U.S. Naval base in Yokosuka, southwest of Tokyo, in June of 2017. The Navy says the commanding officer of a warship that lost seven sailors in a collision off the coast of Japan will be relieved of command, and nearly a dozen other sailors face punishment.\n\nASSOCIATED PRESS Enlarge\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. {"sim": 0.8588235378265381, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9788106", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "kgw.com", "title": "kgw.com", "id": "2860"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://content.tegnanc.com/photo/2017/08/17/636385835500656701-GTY-813430400-92328741_1503007499614_10289176_ver1.0.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 472, "textEnd": 479, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.kgw.com/news/nation-world/commander-of-stricken-destroyer-relieved-after-navy-report-cites-failures/465194256", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:32:00", "title": "Commander of stricken destroyer relieved after Navy report cites failures", "uri": "711145295", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:32:00Z", "time": "22:32:00", "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nWASHINGTON - The head of the Navy's 7th Fleet has relieved the skipper of the USS Fitzgerald and two other officers for losing \"situational awareness\" in the hours leading up to a fatal June collision that left seven sailors dead, the service's deputy chief said Thursday.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, the deputy chief of naval operations, said that Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin relieved Cmdr. Bryce Benson for cause after a report detailing the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and the freighter ACX Crystal was released by the Navy.\n\nThe ship's entire leadership, Moran said, will be relieved, and about a dozen sailors face punishment, including all of the destroyer's watch.\n\nThe command team of three have been relieved. About nine others face non-judicial punishment.\n\nFurther sanctions are possible, Moran said.\n\nAucoin acted swiftly because the investigation indicated serious mistakes were made by the crew, Moran said. The Navy has lost confidence in those sailors.\n\nA \"loud noise\" roused some of the sailors in the Fitzgerald's Berthing 2 compartment, the accident report said. Some in the ship's sleeping and living quarters \"felt an unusual movement,\" while others slept through the initial crash.\n\nSeconds after the ACX Crystal plowed into the starboard side of the Navy's guided missile destroyer at 1:30 a.m., on June 17, seawater gushed through a 13-foot-by-17-foot gash, knocking some from their beds and threatening to drown all 35 sailors in the compartment.\n\n\"Water on deck!\" sailors shouted. \"Get out!\"\n\nThe harrowing moments and hours after the collision -- and the heroism that saved the lives of all but seven of the 35 sailors in Berthing 2 -- are recounted in the report.\n\nIt details the frantic efforts to account for all the sailors in the darkened, flooding compartment, keep the ship afloat, and rescue the ship's commander who dangled outside his crumpled cabin.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dark of night to save their ship,\" wrote Rear Adm. C.F. Williams, commander of Carrier Strike Group Five. Williams' preliminary report looks at the injuries and deaths that resulted from the crash.\n\nThe Fitzgerald, with a crew of about 300 sailors, was about 56 nautical miles southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, at the time of the collision. The sea was calm, and the moon shone through broken clouds. The ship was dark but for navigation lights, and red bulbs inside.\n\nThe Crystal is a far larger ship at 728 feet and 29,000 tons, compared with the Fitzgerald's 505 feet and 9,000 tons. The port side of the Crystal's bow slammed into the Fitzgerald above the waterline, and the bulb-like bow below the surface crunched into the Fitzgerald near Berthing 2.\n\nFlooding in Berthing 2\n\nBerthing 2 held 42 beds in stacks of three bunks, a bathroom, and a lounge area. It contained a lounge with sofas, chairs and a television. After the collision, \"nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald rocked violently, settling into a 7-degree list to her starboard side.\n\n\"One sailor saw another knocked out of his rack by water,\" according to the report. \"Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up.\"\n\nWithin a minute, the compartment had flooded and the water rose. Mattresses, furniture and an exercise bike floated in the aisles. The tilting ship complicated the escape, and the water was neck high by the time many had reached the ladder to climb to safety.\n\nAs the water forced them to the top of the stairs, two sailors reached into the dark water and fished two more shipmates out. The last rescued sailor had been in the bathroom at the time of the crash. The sailors \"pulled him from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported he was taking is final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nThe seven sailors who drowned were nearest the gash, \"directly in the path of the onrushing water.\"\n\n\u00a9 2017 USATODAY.COM\n\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Water_Resources", "wgt": 100, "id": {"sim": 0.8588235378265381, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9905978", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "egyptindependent.com", "title": "egyptindependent.com", "id": "1817"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.egyptindependent.com/app/uploads/2017/08/800-11-3.jpeg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2578, "textEnd": 2585, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.egyptindependent.com/warship-captain-collision-killed-7-lose-command/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:43:00", "title": "Warship captain in collision that killed 7 to lose command - Egypt Independent", "uri": "711472069", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T13:43:00Z", "time": "13:43:00", "body": "Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the June collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and US coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8549019694328308, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9902057", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "syracuse.com", "title": "syracuse.com", "id": "1097"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://image.syracuse.com/home/syr-media/width620/img/us-news/photo/2017/08/18/23256199-standard.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2596, "textEnd": 2603, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.syracuse.com/us-news/index.ssf/2017/08/uss_fitzgerald_navy_captain_command.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:20:00", "title": "US Navy warship captain to lose command after collision that killed 7", "uri": "711462466", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:40:00Z", "time": "09:40:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the June collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of eventsthat took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8549019694328308, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9859212", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wbay.com", "title": "WBAY", "id": "11236"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://media.graytvinc.com/images/USS+Fitzgerald2.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1969, "textEnd": 1976, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wbay.com/content/news/Three-commanders-relieved-of-duty-after-warship-crash-440956403.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:15:00", "title": "Three commanders relieved of duty after warship crash", "uri": "711352210", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:46:00Z", "time": "21:46:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- WASHINGTON (AP) -- The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, who's from Green Bay; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8470588326454163, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9830405", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/1/2017/08/18/06/wire-1157503-1503034950-99_636x382.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 997, "textEnd": 1010, "date": "2017-06-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1392, "imp": true, "textEnd": 1399, "date": "2017-08-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3228, "textEnd": 3235, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 5784, "textEnd": 5798, "date": "2016-09-10", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801568/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:52:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711271025", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:52:00Z", "time": "05:52:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nFILE- This June 17, 2017 file photo shows the damaged USS Fitzgerald near the U.S. Naval base in Yokosuka, southwest of Tokyo. The Navy says the commanding officer of a warship that lost seven sailors in a collision off the coast of Japan will be relieved of command, and nearly a dozen other sailors face punishment. Adm. William Moran, the No. 2 Navy officer, told reporters at the Pentagon on Thursday, Aug. 17, that the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed. (AP Photo/Eugene Hoshiko, File)\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama\n\nFILE- In this Sept. 10, 2016, file photo. Adm. William Moran speaks during the Commissioning of the USS Montgomery in Mobile, Ala. The Navy says the commanding officer of a warship that lost seven sailors in a collision off the coast of Japan will be relieved of command, and nearly a dozen other sailors face punishment. Moran, the No. 2 Navy officer, told reporters at the Pentagon on Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017, that the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed. {"sim": 0.8470588326454163, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371709", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9890316", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "ybw.com", "title": "YBW", "id": "7064"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://keyassets.timeincuk.net/inspirewp/live/wp-content/uploads/sites/22/2017/08/RK17_MP_11_7.png", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.ybw.com/news-from-yachting-boating-world/dutch-east-india-company-ship-rooswijk-finally-gives-up-her-secrets-58436", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:17:00", "title": "Pictures: Dutch East India Company ship Rooswijk finally gives up her secrets - YBW", "uri": "711432156", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:17:00Z", "time": "12:17:00", "body": "The Rooswijk sank on the treacherous Goodwin Sands, off Kent in January 1740 carrying a large cargo of silver ingot and coins. Find out what archaeologists have discovered so far\n\nOrnate carved knife handles, glass bottles and large wooden seaman's chests are among the finds discovered on wreck of the Dutch East India Company ship, Rooswijk.\n\nDutch and British maritime archaeologists are in a race against time to recover and record as much as possible from the protected site.\n\nThe Rooswijk is threatened by currents and shifting sands, and an exploratory study of the wreck last year cemented the urgent need for the current excavation, which is happening throughout the summer.\n\nA diver working on the protection site. Credit: Historic England/RCE\n\nThe wreck, which is owned by the Dutch Government, is classed as 'high risk' on the Heritage at Risk register due to its exposed remains and vulnerability. It is also threatened by an invasive sea worm.\n\nHistoric England, which manages the wreck on behalf of the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, said that never before had an execution of this scale been carried out on a Dutch East India Company wreck.\n\nMaritime archaeologists are concentrating on excavating the storage rooms and living quarters in the stern of the ship.\n\nThe remains of a leather shoe recovered from the wreck of the Dutch ship Rooswijk. Credit: Historic England/RCE\n\nItems such as large wooden seaman's chests, pewter jugs and spoons, glass bottles, ornately carved knife handles and personal items such as shoes have already been recovered from the wreck and brought to shore at Ramsgate where they are being conserved.\n\nThe Rooswijk sank on Goodwin Sands, off Kent, on 8 January 1740.\n\nThe ship was outward bound for Batavia (modern-day Jakarta) with a large cargo of silver ingots and coinage on board.\n\nSome of these have already been recovered during an excavation in 2005.\n\nSpanish coins found in the Rooswijk wreck from 2005. Credit: Collection of the Zeeuws maritiem muZEEum\n\nThe current project is being led by Martijn Manders.\n\n\"The Goodwin Sands has been a treacherous place for ships throughout the centuries and is now a treasure trove for archaeologists. It is also popular with sports divers,\" he explained.\n\n\"The rapidly shifting sands mean that the site is even more exposed now than it was during our initial dives to assess the condition of the Rooswijk last year. This makes the excavation urgent,\" said Mander, who is also maritime heritage programme manager at the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands.\n\nContinued below...\n\nHistoric minesweeper, Arfon, given special protection\n\nLying undiscovered for a century, a rare WW1 trawler and minesweeper, Arfon, has now been given special protection to preserve...\n\nRare emeralds found on wreck of Spanish galleon to be auctioned\n\nEmeralds discovered on the famous Spanish galleon, Nuestra Se\u00f1ora de Atocha, are being sold at the New York City-based auction...\n\nThere are a total of 250 Dutch East India Company shipwrecks around the world, of which only a third have been located.\n\nMaterial recovered from the wreck site of the Rooswijk is being taken ashore to a warehouse in Ramsgate where first-aid conservation will be carried out and the items fully recorded.\n\nFrom here finds will be taken to a Historic England storage facility where work to assess, analyse and conserve them will take place.\n\nThe #Rooswijk1740 project team. Credit: Historic England/RCE\n\nThe finds will be returned to The Netherlands and in future some material may be made available for display in Ramsgate.\n\nMaritime archaeology students are based at the Ramsgate venue and are benefiting from a programme of training delivered by Historic England specialists as well as the opportunity to be involved in the project.\n\nDuring the excavation, public open days and training sessions are being held in Ramsgate, where the extraordinary finds from the Rooswijk will be on display.\n\nMarine archaeologist at Historic England, Alison James, said wrecks, such as the Rooswijk, are \"time capsules that offer a unique glimpse into the past and tell a story.\"\n\n\"Sharing that story with a wide audience is a key part of this project and we look forward to the fascinating insights and discoveries that the Rooswijk excavation will uncover this summer,\" she added.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.843137264251709, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371709", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9795693", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "title": "The Telegraph", "id": "220"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/content/dam/science/2017/08/17/TELEMMGLPICT000137660985-xlarge_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqNJjoeBT78QIaYdkJdEY4CnGTJFJS74MYhNY6w3GNbO8.jpeg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 4714, "dateEnd": "2017-09-16", "imp": true, "textEnd": 4740, "date": "2017-08-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/2017/08/17/lost-crew-18th-century-dutch-treasure-ship-found-coast-kent/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:41:00", "title": "Lost crew of 18th Century Dutch treasure ship found off coast of Kent   ", "uri": "711166540", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:41:00Z", "time": "23:41:00", "body": "The lost crew of an 18th century Dutch merchant ship has been found by marine archaeologists who were racing against time to preserve the wreck before it is destroyed forever by an invasive sea worm.\n\nThe Rooswijk sank in bad weather off the coast of Ramsgate in Kent in January 1740, on her second voyage, and was first discovered by a diver in 2005. But after preliminary excavations it was covered up.\n\nHowever a survey by Historic England last summer revealed the ship was in danger of being destroyed by an invasive ship worm, which is moving to British coastlines from the Mediterranean.\n\nThe shifting and treacherous Goodwin Sands has also left the hull exposed to salt water and air, meaning that archaeologists have had to act fast to record or bring up endangered timbers, canons and artefacts.\n\nNot only have the new excavations uncovered three wooden treasure chests, believed to contain a fortune in silver ingots bound for the East Indies, but for the first time bones of the victims have been found among the wreck.\n\nLittle is known about the crew and passengers of the Rooswijk. As well as sailors, there would have been soldiers protecting the precious cargo, children, wives, and even 'guests of the lower decks' - a polite term for prostitutes. Around 250 people in total were on board when the ship sank and it is thought none survived.\n\nPersonal items of everyday life, including leather shoes, knives, belt buckles and pewter jugs were also recovered from the ship.\n\nMark Dunkley, a marine archaeologist for Historic England, said: \"With the finds that we're bringing up we're seeing how they lived on board, and now with the remains we are seeing how they died as well. They were probably drowned or crushed as the ships collapsed or the cannons came loose and rolled across the decks.\n\n\"We have started finding and recovering bodies. It's a highly significant assemblage because it is so rare to find a lost crew on a shipwreck, captured in time at the moment when a catastrophe happened. In that sense its like an underwater Pompeii.\"\n\nThe team is planning to take DNA samples of the bones to find out whether any of the victims have descendants who are still alive today, as well as X-raying the mysterious seamen's chests to find what treasure lies within, before they are opened up\n\nHowever in the shorter term archaeologists are battling against time, and the elements, to conserve the site from a damaging invader before it is lost forever.\n\n\"The ship is threatened by a new type of ship worm which has come from the Mediterranean Sea and is moving north because the sea around Britain is getting warmer with climate change,\" added Mr Dunkley.\n\n\"It's reached as far north as Felixstowe so any shipwreck below that latitude is threatened by it. It burrows into any wood which speeds up decay and makes the wrecks vulnerable. It attacks the timbers and wooden chests. So it's important that we start conserving these things now to prevent any more damage.\"\n\nThe Rooswijk was owned by the Dutch East India Company and was bound for Jakarta to trade silver and copper for pepper, nutmeg and porcelain when it sank.\n\nSoon after the ship foundered a chest containing letters washed up at Deal in Kent, which identified the captain as Daniel Rousiers, and named around a dozen other crew. But the identities of the rest of the victims were lost in time.\n\nNow a protected wreck site the ships remains are owned by the Dutch government and managed by Historic England on behalf of the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport. Most of the finds, and ingots, will be returned to The Netherlands, although archaeologists are hoping to put some of the treasures on display in Britain.\n\nJohn Glen, Minister for Arts, Heritage and Tourism, said: \"The shipwrecks around our coastline are amazing snapshots of Europe's seafaring and naval history and it is important that we study them while we can.\n\n\"The Rooswijk excavation will help recover and preserve extraordinary artefacts.\"\n\nAround 2,000 ships are known to be wrecked off Goodwin Sands and the shifting landscape mean they are often uncovered by storms or high tides.\n\nMartijn Manders, Project Leader of the Rooswijk Excavation and Maritime Heritage Programme Manager at the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands said: \"The Goodwin sands has been a treacherous place for ships throughout the centuries and is now a treasure trove for archaeologists.\n\n\"The rapidly shifting sands means that the site is even more exposed now than it was during our initial dives to assess the condition of the Rooswijk last year. This makes the excavation urgent.\"\n\nHistoric England will be holding open days to view finds from the ship between August 19 and September 16.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": U.S. Navy", "uri": "711166491", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:41:00Z", "time": "23:41:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - About a dozen U.S. sailors are expected to face punishment for a collision in June between the USS Fitzgerald and a Philippines cargo ship, including the warship's commanding officer and other senior leaders of the ship, the Navy said on Thursday.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters the ship's commanding officer, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed from the vessel because \"we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead.\"\n\nMoran said that in total close to a dozen sailors would face administrative punishment and left open the possibility for further action.\n\nMultiple U.S. and Japanese investigations are under way into how the USS Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe Navy also released a report that provided new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline, killing seven sailors in what was the greatest loss of life on a U.S. Navy vessel since the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 am local time sent water pouring into the U.S. warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report says.\n\nThe commanding officer was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued the commanding officer, who by this point was hanging from the side of the ship.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8392156958580017, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9902070", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nydailynews.com", "title": "Daily News", "id": "422"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://assets.nydailynews.com/polopoly_fs/1.3421962.1503037822!/img/httpImage/image._gen/derivatives/landscape_1200/us-navy-fitzgerald-collision-70791-jpg.", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2597, "textEnd": 2604, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/national/warship-captain-collision-killed-7-lose-command-article-1.3421928", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:20:00", "title": "Warship captain in collision that killed 7 to lose command", "uri": "711462508", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T04:44:00Z", "time": "04:44:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the June collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nTags: newswires associated press us newswires Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet", "date": {"sim": 0.8392156958580017, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371709", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9802236", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bbc.co.uk", "title": "BBC News", "id": "264"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/560/cpsprodpb/12A90/production/_97423467_09duikerrcebijscheepswrakderooswijktijdensdeverkenningin2016.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 932, "dateEnd": "2017-09-16", "imp": true, "textEnd": 958, "date": "2017-08-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-40962097", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:56:00", "title": "Goodwin Sands 'treasure trove' Dutch shipwreck excavated - BBC News", "uri": "711186916", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:56:00Z", "time": "00:56:00", "body": "A ship excavation is expected to reveal a \"treasure trove\" of items and stories from Europe's global trading history.\n\nAn international team of maritime archaeologists are diving, excavating and recording the wreck of Dutch ship the Rooswijk off the Kent coast.\n\nAll 300 shipmen died when the vessel, carrying coins and silver ingots, sank on Goodwin Sands in January 1740.\n\nNever before have any of the Dutch East India Company's 250 wrecks been scientifically excavated on this scale.\n\nHistoric England manages the protected site and is working with the Dutch government, which owns the ship's remains.\n\nIt is only now, after more than 250 years, that the sands have shifted enough to unveil the wreckage.\n\nSome explorations were carried out last year and those finds are being showcased as part of the #Rooswijk1740 project, led and financed by the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands, with open days in Ramsgate between 19 August and 16 September.\n\nThey include a large seaman's chests, pewter jugs, ornately carved wooden knife handles and leather shoes.\n\nThe current mission will see archaeologists delve further into the storage rooms and living quarters in the stern of the ship.\n\nMartijn Manders, project leader of the Rooswijk Excavation and Maritime Heritage programme manager at the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands, said: \"The Goodwin Sands has been a treacherous place for ships throughout the centuries and is now a treasure trove for archaeologists.\n\n\"The rapidly shifting sands mean that the site is even more exposed now than it was during our initial dives to assess the condition of the Rooswijk last year. This makes the excavation urgent.\"\n\nThe wreck is high on the Heritage at Risk register due to its exposed remains and vulnerability to the shifting sands.\n\nAlison James, maritime archaeologist at Historic England, said: \"Wrecks such as the Rooswijk are time capsules that offer a unique glimpse into the past and tell a story.\n\n\"We look forward to the fascinating insights and discoveries that the Rooswijk excavation will uncover this summer.\"", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "timeCrawl": "23:05:00", "title": "US sailors to be punished over collision", "uri": "711155872", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:05:00Z", "time": "23:05:00", "body": "About a dozen US sailors are expected to face punishment for a collision in June between the USS Fitzgerald and a Philippines cargo ship, including the warship's commanding officer and other senior leaders of the ship.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters on Thursday the ship's commanding officer, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed from the vessel because \"we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead.\"\n\nSeven US sailors died in the collision which tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline, marking the greatest loss of life on a US Navy vessel since the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\nMoran said that in total close to a dozen sailors would face administrative punishment and left open the possibility for further action.\n\nMultiple US and Japanese investigations are under way into how the USS Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe Navy also released a report that provided new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe report said the collision sent water pouring into the US warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling.\n\n\"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report says.\n\nThe commanding officer was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued the commanding officer, who by this point was hanging from the side of the ship.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8352941274642944, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9846870", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "title": "South China Morning Post", "id": "273"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://cdn4.i-scmp.com/sites/default/files/styles/620x356/public/images/methode/2017/08/18/8bc5031a-83de-11e7-a767-bc310e55dd10_image_hires_143640.jpg?itok=fyFw0XjC", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2675, "textEnd": 2682, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/2107345/captain-us-destroyer-involved-deadly-collision-lose", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:58:00", "title": "Captain of US destroyer involved in deadly collision to lose command", "uri": "711321042", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:58:00Z", "time": "07:58:00", "body": "Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdmiral William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters on Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the June collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Commander Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Commander Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Admiral Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership\". Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Commander Clay Doss said on Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness\", which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nCrew of US destroyer were likely at fault for collision with cargo ship\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realise what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\nSkipper of cargo ship that almost sank US destroyer sailed in 'same direction' at time of deadly collision\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and US coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime"}, {"sim": 0.8352941274642944, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9819922", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "aurorasentinel.com", "title": "Aurora Sentinel", "id": "2965"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/aurorasentinel/asuplads/20170817220800/AP17229809652732.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1922, "textEnd": 1929, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.aurorasentinel.com/news/nation-world/senior-officer-damaged-navy-ship-relieved-command/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:13:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged Navy ship to be relieved of command - Aurora Sentinel", "uri": "711239289", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T04:13:00Z", "time": "04:13:00", "body": "WASHINGTON | The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed.
