{"sim": 0.8039215803146362, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9817569", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "af.reuters.com", "title": "af.reuters.com", "id": "605"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://s3.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170817&t=2&i=1197568150&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXNPED7G1VJ", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1277, "textEnd": 1284, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFKCN1AX2TG", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:49:00", "title": "U.S. Navy to remove senior leaders of warship after deadly June crash", "uri": "711232785", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:49:00Z", "time": "03:49:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. Navy will relieve the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that collided with a Philippine container ship in June off the coast of Japan, the Navy said on Thursday,\n\nA separate official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the USS Fitzgerald, killing seven Navy sailors.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters that the USS Fitzgerald's commander, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed. \"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" he said.\n\nMoran said about another nine sailors would face administrative punishments, and he left open the possibility of further action.\n\nWhile an investigation into the cause of the crash was still under way, Moran said there was enough evidence to take initial action.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nMultiple U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nUnder the maritime rules of the road, the commercial vessel had the right-of-way, and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard, or right, side was likely at fault.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, or CIC, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nThe Navy also released a report with new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline. The death of the seven sailors was the greatest loss of life on a U.S. warship since 2000, when Islamic extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 a.m. local time sent water pouring into the U.S. warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nThe commanding officer, Bryce Benson, who is one of the officers who will be relieved of his post, was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, {"sim": 0.8039215803146362, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9798114", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 27, "textEnd": 33, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1300, "textEnd": 1307, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801156/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:08:00", "title": "U.S. Navy to remove senior leaders of warship after deadly June crash", "uri": "711173983", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:08:00Z", "time": "00:08:00", "body": "By Idrees Ali\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 17 (Reuters) - The U.S. Navy will relieve the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that collided with a Philippine container ship in June off the coast of Japan, the Navy said on Thursday,\n\nA separate official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the USS Fitzgerald, killing seven Navy sailors.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters that the USS Fitzgerald's commander, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed. \"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" he said.\n\nMoran said about another nine sailors would face administrative punishments, and he left open the possibility of further action.\n\nWhile an investigation into the cause of the crash was still under way, Moran said there was enough evidence to take initial action.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nMultiple U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nUnder the maritime rules of the road, the commercial vessel had the right-of-way, and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard, or right, side was likely at fault.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, or CIC, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nThe Navy also released a report with new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline. The death of the seven sailors was the greatest loss of life on a U.S. warship since 2000, when Islamic extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbor.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 a.m. local time sent water pouring into the U.S. warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nThe commanding officer, Bryce Benson, who is one of the officers who will be relieved of his post, was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship. {"sim": 0.8039215803146362, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9833396", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "newsobserver.com", "title": "The News&Observer", "id": "8851"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/3ljwxf/picture167866927/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Navy_Fitzgerald_Collision_52732.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2578, "textEnd": 2585, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article167909112.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:18:00", "title": "Warship captain in collision that killed 7 to lose command", "uri": "711286188", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:18:00Z", "time": "06:18:00", "body": "Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the June collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": senior leaders of warship after deadly June crash", "uri": "711173401", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:05:00Z", "time": "00:05:00", "body": "Admiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters that the USS Fitzgerald's commander, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed.\n\nThe U.S. Navy will relieve the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that collided with a Philippine container ship in June off the coast of Japan, the Navy said on Thursday,\n\nA separate official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the USS Fitzgerald, killing seven Navy sailors.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters that the USS Fitzgerald's commander, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed. \"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" he said.\n\nMoran said about another nine sailors would face administrative punishments, and he left open the possibility of further action.\n\nWhile an investigation into the cause of the crash was still under way, Moran said there was enough evidence to take initial action.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nMultiple U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nUnder the maritime rules of the road, the commercial vessel had the right-of-way, and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard, or right, side was likely at fault.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, or CIC, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nThe Navy also released a report with new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline. The death of the seven sailors was the greatest loss of life on a U.S. warship since 2000, when Islamic extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 a.m. local time sent water pouring into the U.S. warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nThe commanding officer, Bryce Benson, who is one of the officers who will be relieved of his post, was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\n(This Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Adm. Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said on Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nCmdr. Doss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Adm. Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nMr. Yoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36044527.ece/b350e/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-bf6f65b8-84d4-417e-9552-d6fd5c4bfabf_I1.jpg\n\nThe captain of a US warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and more than a dozen others face punishment.\n\nAdmiral William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters the senior leaders on the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship.\n\nThey are the commanding officer, Commander Bryce Benson, the executive officer, Commander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Admiral Joseph Aucoin, commander of the navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Admiral Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, he said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced on Friday after they are completed.\n\nAdmiral Moran said the actions will be taken shortly, although the investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" he said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is continuing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 in an accident-prone area known for congestion within Japanese territorial waters. what happened when the freighter hit the USS Fitzgerald, killing seven Navy sailors.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters that the USS Fitzgerald's commander, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed. \"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" he said.\n\nMoran said about another nine sailors would face administrative punishments, and he left open the possibility of further action.\n\nWhile an investigation into the cause of the crash was still under way, Moran said there was enough evidence to take initial action.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nMultiple US and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nUnder the maritime rules of the road, the commercial vessel had the right-of-way, and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard, or right, side was likely at fault.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, or CIC, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nThe Navy also released a report with new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline. The death of the seven sailors was the greatest loss of life on a US warship since 2000, when Islamic extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbor.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 a.m. local time sent water pouring into the US warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nThe commanding officer, Bryce Benson, who is one of the officers who will be relieved of his post, was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, {"sim": 0.7921568751335144, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9833968", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "title": "Breaking News.ie", "id": "325"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "/remote/media.central.ie/media/images/u/USSFitzgeraldCollisionDamageJun2017_large.jpg?width=600&s=bn-802532", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1871, "textEnd": 1878, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.breakingnews.ie/world/warship-captain-relieved-of-duty-over-collision-that-left-seven-sailors-dead-802532.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:24:00", "title": "Warship captain relieved of duty over collision that left seven sailors dead", "uri": "711287637", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:24:00Z", "time": "06:24:00", "body": "The captain of a US warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and more than a dozen others face punishment.\n\nAdmiral William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters the senior leaders on the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship.\n\nThey are the commanding officer, Commander Bryce Benson, the executive officer, Commander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Admiral Joseph Aucoin, commander of the navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Admiral Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, he said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced on Friday after they are completed.\n\nAdmiral Moran said the actions will be taken shortly, although the investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" he said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is continuing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 in an accident-prone area known for congestion within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted.\n\nThe bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct.\n\nIt commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help others out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said probably saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realise what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nAP", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7921568751335144, "details": {"liCnt": 9, "pinCnt": 3}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9798796", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "time.com", "title": "TIME", "id": "73"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://timedotcom.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/us-navy-cdr-bryce-benson-officer-captain1.jpg?w=720", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1925, "textEnd": 1932, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://time.com/4906057/navy-warship-crash-william-moran-uss-fitzgerald/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:14:00", "title": "Captain of Navy Warship Involved in Deadly Crash Relieved of Command", "uri": "711176652", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:14:00Z", "time": "00:14:00", "body": "(WASHINGTON) -- The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7882353067398071, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9831021", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "federalnewsradio.com", "title": "Federal News Radio", "id": "9518"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://federalnewsradio.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Navy_Fitzgerald_Collision_52732.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2788, "textEnd": 2795, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/world-news/2017/08/navy-hands-penalties-on-collision-both-ships-made-errors/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:57:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711272697", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:57:00Z", "time": "05:57:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nSponsored Content: How is your agency managing and maximizing its data? Share your opinions in a Federal News Radio survey.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nPostal Service may be able to raise price of stamps this fall\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7882353067398071, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9830759", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wmcactionnews5.com", "title": "WMC Action News 5", "id": "191"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://images.worldnow.com/AP/images/14686833_G.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2599, "textEnd": 2606, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36164201/navy-hands-penalties-on-collision-both-ships-made-errors", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:56:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711272167", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:56:00Z", "time": "05:56:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"sim": 0.7843137383460999, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9812499", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/uss-fitzgerald.jpg?w=759", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 37, "textEnd": 52, "date": "2017-08-18", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 69, "textEnd": 82, "date": "2017-06-18", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1336, "textEnd": 1343, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/dozen-us-sailors-to-be-punished-for-june-collision-us-navy-4802020/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:54:00", "title": "Dozen US sailors to be punished for June collision: US Navy", "uri": "711219398", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:54:00Z", "time": "02:54:00", "body": "By: Reuters | Washington | Published:August 18, 2017 8:11 am In this June 18, 2017, file photo, damaged USS Fitzgerald is docked at the US Naval base in Yokosuka, southwest of Tokyo, after colliding with Philippine-flagged container ship ACX Crystal off Japan. (Source: AP Photo/File) Doklam India-China standoff: Japan throws weight behind India, BhutanRetired HC judge to probe J Jayalalithaa death: CM E K PalaniswamiFor 2019, Amit Shah rolls out 350-plus blueprint for BJP\n\nAbout a dozen US sailors are expected to face punishment for a collision in June between the USS Fitzgerald and a Philippines cargo ship, including the warship's commanding officer and other senior leaders of the ship, the Navy said on Thursday. Admiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters the ship's commanding officer, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed from the vessel because \"we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead.\"\n\nMoran said that in total close to a dozen sailors would face administrative punishment and left open the possibility for further action. Multiple US and Japanese investigations are underway into how the USS Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe Navy also released a report that provided new details of the crash and its aftermath. The collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline, killing seven sailors in what was the greatest loss of life on a US Navy vessel since the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen's Aden harbor in 2000. The report said the collision at 1:30 am local time sent water pouring into the US warship. \"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision. \"Lockers were floating past him... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape. \"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report says.\n\nThe commanding officer was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door. \"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said. The sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued the commanding officer, who by this point was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express {"sim": 0.7843137383460999, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9799367", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "magicvalley.com", "title": "Twin Falls Times-News", "id": "8898"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/7f/27f71a17-06c9-54fd-8633-baf346fbb07f/599627b0293cf.image.jpg?crop=512%2C288%2C0%2C20&resize=512%2C288&order=crop%2Cresize", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1928, "textEnd": 1935, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://magicvalley.com/news/national/govt-and-politics/senior-officer-on-damaged-ship-to-be-relieved-of-command/article_82473b09-ffe3-5577-b6c9-90951de7f957.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:20:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged ship to be relieved of command", "uri": "711178070", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:20:00Z", "time": "00:20:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nGet news headlines sent daily to your inbox Sign Up! I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7843137383460999, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9829600", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "963"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2600, "textEnd": 2607, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_NAVY_FITZGERALD_COLLISION_ASOL-?SITE=NCHIC&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:45:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711268666", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:38:00Z", "time": "05:38:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n---\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.", "date": {"sim": 0.7803921699523926, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9822367", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "financialexpress.com", "title": "The Financial Express", "id": "4684"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://images.financialexpress.com/2017/08/carsh.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1115, "textEnd": 1122, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.financialexpress.com/world-news/commander-dismissed-after-us-navy-ship-crashed-off-japan/813300/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:32:00", "title": "Commander dismissed after US Navy ship crashed off Japan", "uri": "711245417", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T04:32:00Z", "time": "04:32:00", "body": "Among those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\nThe commander of a US Navy ship that collided with a Philippine-flagged cargo ship off Japan, killing seven American seamen, will be relieved of duty and several other sailors face punishment, a senior admiral said today. Among those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations. \"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nSeven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17. Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed by today. About a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total. \"If it's clear to (Aucoin) that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions,\" Moran said. Moran said the sailors could face further punishments later one, depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes. \"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\nAged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping quarters a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the side of the Fitzgerald. Moran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into what happened in the immediate aftermath of the crash. The report found that all seven victims died in the line of duty and their deaths were not due to any misconduct on their part. Investigators praised the quick-thinking and \"heroic\" actions of sailors who worked to save shipmates, one of whom had to be dragged from his bunk in a flooding sleeping area as waters quickly rose. One sailor who was rescued moments before he would have drowned reported that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\" Additionally, the report describes how the ship's commanding officer was injured when the merchant ship Crystal struck his cabin, trapping him inside. Fellow sailors had to smash and pry his door open before retrieving the commander, who was \"hanging from the side of the ship. The officer was eventually medically evacuated by helicopter. Moran praised the actions of the drowned sailors. The last of them to be buried was laid to rest on Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery outside Washington.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9807318", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "vancouversun.com", "title": "The Vancouver Sun", "id": "1553"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.vancouversun.com/cms/binary/14245570.png", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2028, "textEnd": 2035, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.vancouversun.com/news/world/captain+navy+destroyer+fatal+collision+japan+relieved+command/14245433/story.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:52:00", "title": "Captain of U.S. Navy destroyer in fatal collision off Japan to be relieved of command", "uri": "711203838", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:52:00Z", "time": "01:52:00", "body": "ShareAdjustCommentPrint\n\nBy Robert Burns\n\nWASHINGTON \u00e2\u0080\" The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship\u00e2\u0080\u0099s command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy\u00e2\u0080\u0099s investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cSerious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe bridge team,\u00e2\u0080\u009d or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship\u00e2\u0080\u0099s bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \u00e2\u0080\u009clost situational awareness,\u00e2\u0080\u009d which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew\u00e2\u0080\u0099s efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald\u00e2\u0080\u0099s right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship\u00e2\u0080\u0099s crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space \u00e2\u0080\" actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cNo damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\u00e2\u0080\u009d the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cAt least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\u00e2\u0080\u009d it said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Topic", "wgt": {"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9842449", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "freemalaysiatoday.com", "title": "Free Malaysia Today", "id": "10786"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://s3media.freemalaysiatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/us-ship.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1119, "textEnd": 1126, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/world/2017/08/18/us-navy-removes-commanders-of-warship-in-deadly-crash/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:27:00", "title": "US Navy removes commanders of warship in deadly crash", "uri": "711310075", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:27:00Z", "time": "07:27:00", "body": "Admiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\nWASHINGTON/TOKYO: The US Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a US warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippine container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven US sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the US Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a US warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the US Seventh Fleet said in a media release.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision. The Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course, it said.\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral US and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nCommander Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\", the Seventh Fleet said.\n\nCommander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\", it said.\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\n\"Serious mistakes\"\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri":
