{"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9831212", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "kiro7.com", "title": "KIRO", "id": "1082"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://cmgfeeds.cmgdigital.com/photo/2017/08/18/Navy_Fitzgerald_Collision_52732_8890428_ver1.0_1280_720.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2287, "textEnd": 2294, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.kiro7.com/news/world/navy-hands-penalties-on-collision-both-ships-made-errors/594543172", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:59:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711273536", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:59:00Z", "time": "05:59:00", "body": "Adm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9833320", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.com", "title": "Business Insider", "id": "711"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://static6.businessinsider.com/image/59962bf5f1a850bb028b5cca-1190-625/nearly-a-dozen-us-sailors-to-be-punished-after-deadly-uss-fitzgerald-collision.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 178, "textEnd": 191, "date": "2017-06-18", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1097, "textEnd": 1104, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.businessinsider.com/uss-fitzgerald-sailors-punished-7-2017-8", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:18:00", "title": "Nearly a dozen US sailors to be punished after deadly USS Fitzgerald collision", "uri": "711285329", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:57:00Z", "time": "23:57:00", "body": "The Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald, damaged by colliding with a Philippine-flagged merchant vessel, is seen at the US naval base in Yokosuka, Japan, June 18, 2017. Toru Hanai/Reuters\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - About a dozen US sailors are expected to face punishment for a collision in June between the USS Fitzgerald and a Philippines cargo ship, including the warship's commanding officer and other senior leaders of the ship, the Navy said on Thursday.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters the ship's commanding officer, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed from the vessel because \"we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead.\"\n\nMoran said that in total close to a dozen sailors would face administrative punishment and left open the possibility for further action.\n\nMultiple US and Japanese investigations are under way into how the USS Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline, killing seven sailors in what was the greatest loss of life on a US Navy vessel since the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen's Aden harbor in 2000.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 am local time sent water pouring into the US warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report says.\n\nThe commanding officer was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued the commanding officer, who by this point was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\n(Reporting by Idrees Ali; Editing by Yara Bayoumy and James Dalgleish)", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Games/Online/Roleplaying", "wgt": 100, "id": 956, "label": "dmoz/Games/Online/Roleplaying"}], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": {"sim": 0.772549033164978, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9829311", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "seattletimes.com", "title": "The Seattle Times", "id": "844"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://static.seattletimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/c401d983bfcc435592190297e3f37b7b-780x517.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 2600, "textEnd": 2607, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/navy-hands-penalties-on-collision-both-ships-made-errors/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:42:00", "title": "Navy hands penalties on collision, both ships made errors", "uri": "711267901", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:42:00Z", "time": "05:42:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Poor seamanship and flaws in keeping watch contributed to a collision between a Navy destroyer and a commercial container ship that killed seven sailors, Navy officials said, announcing that the warship captain will be relieved of command and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. Clay Doss said Friday.\n\nAdministrative penalties were handed out to seven others that were members of the watch teams, he said, without giving details. All 14 remain in the Navy, but they will be assigned to other jobs, he said.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed, but enough details were available to decide on Friday's actions, the Navy said.\n\nDoss said the specifics of what led to the collision were related to preparations for litigation and cannot be released.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nWithin 30 to 60 seconds, the berthing was flooded, and the water was waist deep, the study said. Mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle were floating in the aisles.\n\nThe sailors tried to escape and helped each other, looking for their mates. One sailor got pinned between floating lockers and was barely able to pull himself free. The seven sailors who died were sleeping in the area closest to and directly in the path of the incoming water, the study found.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nThe Japanese and U.S. coast guards are conducting their own investigations.\n\nJapan's Coast Guard is \"not in a position to make any comments on the Navy's investigation,\" spokesman Yoshihito Nakamura said.\n\nYoshinori Fukushima, spokesman for the operators of the container ship ACX Crystal, also declined to comment, saying they had yet to see the Navy report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press Writer Yuri Kageyama in Tokyo contributed to this report.\n\nFollow her on Twitter at https://twitter.com/yurikageyama\n\nHer work can be found at https://www.apnews.com/search/yuri%20kageyama", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7686274647712708, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9873638", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "vanguardngr.com", "title": "Vanguard", "id": "2237"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://cdn.vanguardngr.com/vangurad.png", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1418, "textEnd": 1425, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/08/breaking-navy-removes-2-commanding-officers/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:39:00", "title": "Breaking: Navy removes 2 commanding officers - Vanguard News", "uri": "711389877", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:39:00Z", "time": "10:39:00", "body": "The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippines container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nThe Seventh Fleet said that Cdr. Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\".\n\nThe fleet also said that Cdr. Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\".\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbor in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a statement.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signaled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision.\n\nIn the report, the captain said the Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course.\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling.\n\n\"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped.\n\nThe last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing II, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": {"sim": 0.7647058963775635, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9803995", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "news.abs-cbn.com", "title": "ABS-CBN News", "id": "1007"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://sa.kapamilya.com/absnews/abscbnnews/media/2017/overseas/06/17/uss-fitzgerald-collide.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 888, "textEnd": 895, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://news.abs-cbn.com/overseas/08/18/17/commander-dismissed-after-us-navy-ship-crashed-off-japan", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:15:00", "title": "Commander dismissed after US Navy ship crashed off Japan", "uri": "711193695", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:15:00Z", "time": "01:15:00", "body": "WASHINGTON, United States - The commander of a US Navy ship that collided with a Philippine-flagged cargo ship off Japan, killing seven American seamen, will be relieved of duty and several other sailors face punishment, a senior admiral said Thursday.\n\nAmong those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nSeven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17.\n\nVice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed by the end of Friday.\n\nAbout a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total.\n\n\"If it's clear to (Aucoin) that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nMoran said the sailors could face further punishments later one, depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes.\n\n\"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\n- 'Heroic' actions -\n\nAged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping quarters a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the side of the Fitzgerald.\n\nMoran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into what happened in the immediate aftermath of the crash.\n\nThe report found that all seven victims died in the line of duty and their deaths were not due to any misconduct on their part.\n\nInvestigators praised the quick-thinking and \"heroic\" actions of sailors who worked to save shipmates, one of whom had to be dragged from his bunk in a flooding sleeping area as waters quickly rose.\n\nOne sailor who was rescued moments before he would have drowned reported that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nAdditionally, the report describes how the ship's commanding officer was injured when the merchant ship Crystal struck his cabin, trapping him inside.\n\nFellow sailors had to smash and pry his door open before retrieving the commander, who was \"hanging from the side of the ship. The officer was eventually medically evacuated by helicopter.\n\nMoran praised the actions of the drowned sailors. The last of them to be buried was laid to rest Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery outside Washington.\n\n\u00a9 Agence France-Presse", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7647058963775635, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9820435", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 951, "textEnd": 958, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-us-navy-citing-poor-seamanship-removes-commanders-of-warship-in-deadly-crash-2533728", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:14:00", "title": "U.S. Navy, citing poor seamanship, removes commanders of warship in deadly crash", "uri": "711239813", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T04:14:00Z", "time": "04:14:00", "body": "The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippine container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a media release.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision. The Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course, it said.\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nCommander Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\", the Seventh Fleet said.\n\nCommander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\", it said.\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\n\"SERIOUS MISTAKES\"\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency {"sim": 0.7647058963775635, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9798243", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch", "id": "1117"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/stltoday.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/b7/2b763ed1-83d7-563d-852d-fe8497efa4a2/59962a854ec79.image.jpg?crop=437%2C328%2C37%2C0&resize=437%2C328&order=crop%2Cresize", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1928, "textEnd": 1935, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.stltoday.com/news/national/govt-and-politics/senior-officer-on-damaged-ship-to-be-relieved-of-command/article_fe1b3de4-cd8c-58d9-9021-f53221569a45.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:09:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged ship to be relieved of command", "uri": "711174480", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:09:00Z", "time": "00:09:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the Navy's second-ranking admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space -- actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.\n\nPolitical Fix from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nBe informed. Get our free political newsletter featuring local and national updates and analysis.\n\nThis field is required. Premium Times Nigeria", "uri": "711372982", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:02:00Z", "time": "10:02:00", "body": "The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippines container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nThe Seventh Fleet said that Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\".\n\nThe fleet also said that Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\".\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a statement.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision.\n\nIn the report, the captain said the Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course.\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nBill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling.\n\n\"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped.\n\nThe last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing II, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied ship crashed off Japan", "uri": "711218059", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:48:00Z", "time": "02:48:00", "body": "The commander of a US Navy ship that collided with a Philippine-flagged cargo ship off Japan, killing seven American seamen, will be relieved of duty and several other sailors face punishment, a senior admiral said today.\n\nAmong those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nSeven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17.\n\nVice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed by today.\n\nAbout a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total.\n\n\"If it's clear to (Aucoin) that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nMoran said the sailors could face further punishments later one, depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes.\n\n\"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\nAged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping quarters a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the side of the Fitzgerald.\n\nMoran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into what happened in the immediate aftermath of the crash.\n\nThe report found that all seven victims died in the line of duty and their deaths were not due to any misconduct on their part.\n\nInvestigators praised the quick-thinking and \"heroic\" actions of sailors who worked to save shipmates, one of whom had to be dragged from his bunk in a flooding sleeping area as waters quickly rose.\n\nOne sailor who was rescued moments before he would have drowned reported that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\" Additionally, the report describes how the ship's commanding officer was injured when the merchant ship Crystal struck his cabin, trapping him inside.\n\nFellow sailors had to smash and pry his door open before retrieving the commander, who was \"hanging from the side of the ship. The officer was eventually medically evacuated by helicopter.\n\nMoran praised the actions of the drowned sailors. {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9824777", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "title": "Channel NewsAsia", "id": "1555"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Japan"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "T\u014dky\u014d-to"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/image/9134608/16x9/991/529/63dce75a0e43acc5aee35ba700b1e01d/lL/uss-fitzgerald-sits-in-dry-dock-4-during-repairs-in-yokosuka-5.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 969, "textEnd": 976, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/us-navy--citing-poor-seamanship--removes-commanders-of-warship-in-deadly-crash-9134612", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:58:00", "title": "US Navy, citing poor seamanship, removes commanders of warship in deadly crash", "uri": "711254609", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T04:58:00Z", "time": "04:58:00", "body": "WASHINGTON/TOKYO: The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippine container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a media release.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision. The Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course, it said.\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nCommander Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\", the Seventh Fleet said.\n\nCommander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\", it said.\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\n\"SERIOUS MISTAKES\"\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\n(Reporting by Idrees Ali in WASHINGTON and Tim Kelly in TOKYO; Editing by Yara Bayoumy, John Walcott, Leslie Adler and Paul Tait)", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation Among those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters. Seven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17. Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed bytoday. About a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total.\n\n\"If it's clear to (Aucoin) that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions,\" Moran said. Moran said the sailors could face further punishments later one, depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes. \"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said. Aged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping quarters a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the side of the Fitzgerald. Moran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into whathappened in the immediate aftermath of the crash.\n\nThe report found that all seven victims died in the line of duty and their deaths were not due to any misconduct on their part. Investigators praised the quick-thinking and \"heroic\"actions of sailors who worked to save shipmates, one of whom had to be dragged from his bunk in a flooding sleeping area as waters quickly rose. One sailor who was rescued moments before he would have drowned reported that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nAdditionally, the report describes how the ship's commanding officer was injured when the merchant ship Crystal struck his cabin, trapping him inside. Fellow sailors had to smash and pry his door open before retrieving the commander, who was \"hanging from the side of the ship. The officer was eventually medically evacuated by helicopter. Moran praised the actions of the drowned sailors. The last of them to be buried was laid to rest on Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery outside Washington.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9839504", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "japantoday.com", "title": "Japan Today", "id": "18472"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://japantoday-asset.scdn3.secure.raxcdn.com/img/store/da/5f/9307d488178f3d833fa381f0793cb223bc50/ussfitz.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 950, "textEnd": 957, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/national/U.S.-Navy-to-remove-senior-officers-of-warship-after-deadly-June-collision-of-Japan", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:06:00", "title": "U.S. Navy removes senior officers of warship in deadly collision", "uri": "711302078", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:06:00Z", "time": "07:06:00", "body": "The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippine container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbor in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a media release.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision. The Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course, it said..\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nCommander Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\", the Seventh Fleet said.\n\nCommander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\", it said.\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling.\"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\n\n\u00a9 (c) Copyright Thomson Reuters 2017.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9789516", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 55, "textEnd": 61, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 939, "textEnd": 946, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/dozen-u-s-sailors-to-be-punished-for-june-collision-u-s-navy/articleshow/60111292.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:45:00", "title": "Dozen U.S. sailors to be punished for June collision -U.S. Navy - Times of India", "uri": "711149504", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:45:00Z", "time": "22:45:00", "body": "(Adds details from report)\n\nBy Idrees Ali\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 17 (Reuters) - About a dozen U.S. sailors are expected to face punishment for a collision in June between the USS Fitzgerald and a Philippines cargo ship, including the warship's commanding officer and other senior leaders of the ship, the Navy said on Thursday.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told reporters the ship's commanding officer, executive officer and master chief petty officer would be removed from the vessel because \"we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead.\"\n\nMoran said that in total close to a dozen sailors would face administrative punishment and left open the possibility for further action.\n\nMultiple U.S. and Japanese investigations are under way into how the USS Fitzgerald, a guided missile destroyer, and the much larger ACX Crystal container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe Navy also released a report that provided new details of the crash and its aftermath.\n\nThe collision tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline, killing seven sailors in what was the greatest loss of life on a U.S. Navy vessel since the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen's Aden harbor in 2000.\n\nThe report said the collision at 1:30 am local time sent water pouring into the U.S. warship.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nWithin 60 seconds, the berthing was completely flooded. More than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report says.\n\nThe commanding officer was trapped in his cabin, and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves together with a belt and rescued the commanding officer, who by this point was hanging from the side of the ship. (Reporting by Idrees Ali; Editing by Yara Bayoumy and James Dalgleish)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371709", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9864172", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "title": "The Guardian", "id": "260"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/67eb6f9caa82975edae20906de75ac911f8f0e31/240_0_3600_2160/master/3600.jpg?w=1200&h=630&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=crop&crop=faces%2Centropy&bm=normal&ba=bottom%2Cleft&blend64=aHR0cHM6Ly91cGxvYWRzLmd1aW0uY28udWsvMjAxNi8wNi8wNy9vdmVybGF5LWxvZ28tMTIwMC05MF9vcHQucG5n&s=b091f51d8680453da4ea8e9872fc6f11", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 5011, "dateEnd": "2017-09-16", "imp": true, "textEnd": 5037, "date": "2017-08-19", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2726, "textEnd": 2735, "date": "-01-07", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/aug/18/treasure-and-intrigue-scientists-unravel-story-of-1740-kent-shipwreck", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:42:00", "title": "Treasure and intrigue: scientists unravel story of 1740 Kent shipwreck", "uri": "711364083", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:37:00Z", "time": "09:37:00", "body": "Covered with seaweed, bits of shell and pebbles concreted into lumps of corroded iron, the wooden seaman's chest from the Dutch East India ship Rooswijk remains tantalisingly locked after almost 300 years. It will take months of conservation work before the archaeologists discover whether it holds some of the silver treasure the ship was carrying, or a long dead sailor's old socks.\n\nA joint excavation by divers and scientists from Historic England and the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands is gradually unravelling the story of the last hours of the Rooswijk, which ran aground and sank in the Goodwin Sands off Kent in January 1740 with the loss of every life on board - almost 250 sailors, soldiers and passengers.\n\nFinds already brought ashore in Ramsgate include a shoe still showing the dint of the sailor's heel on the instep, glass bottles and a fancy wine glass with an air twist stem, which must have come from the captain's cabin, pewter jugs, an onion jar, tiles from the cooking stove still scorched by the last meal, three wooden chests, one human thigh bone - and some genuine old-fashioned treasure in the form of beautiful Mexican silver dollars, minted just a few years before the wreck, and older, cruder chopped-up pieces of eight.\n\nSeveral cannon and two huge sea anchors still lie in the silt on the seabed.\n\nA quantity of silver was salvaged in 2005 and returned to the Dutch government, which still owns the wreck, but the project leader, Martijn Martens, maritime cultural heritage manager at the Netherlands agency, said they had no idea how much silver was actually on board.\n\n\"We have many questions,\" Martens said. \"We do not even know what this ship really looked like.\"\n\nThe ship was bound for Jakarta to buy spices and porcelain, and was carrying quantities of silver bullion and ingots, but silver was worth far more in the East Indies than in Amsterdam, and smuggling - at every level, from a chestful in an officer's cabin to a few coins stitched into a sailor's belt - was a well-known way of supplementing wages.\n\nThe first finds of silver scattered in small quantities throughout the wreckage are bearing this out, and also show that those who couldn't afford silver were bringing any kind of scrap metal they could lay hands on, knowing it would all have a value at their destination.\n\nIn 1740 it was months before anyone wondered what had happened to the Rooswijk, and it was only when the ship failed to make landfall at the Cape of Good Hope, after what should have been months at sea, that the company began to worry. A chest of letters washed up on the English coast revealed the truth: the ship, only a few years old and on her second voyage, having left Amsterdam on 7 January, had been driven by a storm the next day on to the Goodwin, the dreaded Ship Swallower, which has claimed the lives of thousands of seafarers - a 19th-century steam ship lies on the seabed 100 metres from the 18th-century three-master. The evidence from the wreck site is that the heavily laden ship sank like a stone, with the loss of everyone on board.\n\nThe ship is an officially protected wreck site because of its historic importance. Of the 250 Dutch East India ships known to have been wrecked, only a third have been located and this is the first to be scientifically excavated.\n\nThe excavation was judged urgent because the deep silty sand that has protected the remains for so long is shifting now due to changing tidal patterns, leaving timbers exposed and decaying - and vulnerable to treasure hunters.\n\nIt may never be possible, or even desirable, to open the mystery chest. Conventional x-rays often don't reveal much of heavily concreted objects. Angela Middleton, a conservation expert at Historic England, hopes to persuade the customs authorities to bring along one of the scanners they use at the port to check for people and goods hidden in lorries, and see if it shows up anything.\n\n\"We might find out it is impossible to open the chest without destroying it. Or we might find out what is in it and decide it's just not worth even trying to open it,\" she said.\n\nManders described the Goodwin Sands as \" a treasure trove for archaeologists\". There have been protests over plans by the Dover port authority to dredge there to improve the shipping channel and also extract sand and gravel for docks development work. The sands also became the last resting place of many downed Battle of Britain air crew, and others lost in the second world war. Sir Mark Rylance, who starred in the recent blockbuster film Dunkirk, described the proposal as disrespectful and insensitive.\n\nAlison James, a maritime archaeologist at Historic England, said they were in discussions with Dover, and though the Rooswijk lies some distance from the proposed dredging area, they would be monitoring carefully its condition and the other protected wrecks.\n\nThere will be open days where the public can see many of the finds at the excavation's warehouse base in Ramsgate Marina on 19 August and 16 September.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Social_Sciences/Archaeology", {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371709", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9863727", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2017/08/18/09/4358F01800000578-0-image-a-19_1503046646014.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801932/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:38:00", "title": "Divers uncover secrets buried on the Dutch ship Rooswijk", "uri": "711362336", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T09:38:00Z", "time": "09:38:00", "body": "By Colin Fernandez Science Correspondent For The Daily Mail\n\nDivers are racing against time to preserve the wreck of a Dutch treasure ship which sank off the British coast.\n\nThe Dutch merchant ship De Rooswijk carrying chests of silver ingots, silver dollars and pieces of eight hit treacherous sandbanks in January 1740.\n\nThe ship, on its way to buy nutmeg and pepper in the East Indies sank, killing all on board - some 250 men, women and children.\n\nScroll down for video\n\nDivers are racing against time to preserve the wreck of a Dutch treasure ship which sank off the British coast (pictured). Partial recovery work was carried out on the wreck in 2005 and parts of its cargo recovered, but conservationists fear that the wreck could be destroyed\n\nBURIED TREASURE\n\nTo recover objects, the team use a machine to carefully suck up the sand from the site, revealing buried artefacts.\n\nThree large chests have been recovered from the current excavation which may contain bullion.\n\nThe archaeologists will carefully open the chests slowly after they are X-rayed to discover what is inside, to ensure nothing might be inadvertently damaged in the process.\n\nThe divers have also recovered spoons, shoes, belt buckles, pipes, pewter tankards, glassware, ornate knife handles, and musket balls.\n\nSeveral cannons are still on the sea bed.\n\nSeveral silver 'Pillar dollars' - minted in Mexico - have been found on the ship along with silver pieces of eight.\n\nThe research team believe that some of the silver was being smuggled by sailors for their own personal trade.\n\nPartial recovery work was carried out on the wreck in 2005 - and parts of its cargo recovered, but conservationists fear that the wreck could be destroyed.\n\nNow several reinforced wooden chests - expected to contain precious metals -have been recovered and are being stored under water.\n\nBut now conservationists, fearing that the ship's was threatening to break up underwater have launched an urgent recovery operation at Goodwin Sands, in Kent.\n\nThe shifting sands and strong currents off the coast of Deal threaten to destroy the wreck in the next few years.\n\nWhile buried in sand the ship is protected.\n\nBut as the sand rolls, exposing the ship's timbers, this puts it at the mercy of the tides, as well as from rogue treasure hunters.\n\nMartijn Manders, leader of the excavation, and working for the Dutch government, owns of the vessel said: 'The Goodwin Sands has been a treacherous place for ships throughout the centuries and is now a treasure trove for archaeologists.'\n\nA further threat is from a Mediterranean shipworm, increasingly finding its way to the UK, which could chew away at the timbers.\n\nMartin Dunkley, a marine archaeologist from Historic England, which is in charge of protecting the site said: 'The ship is threatened by a new type of ship worm which has come from the Mediterranean Sea and is moving north because the sea around Britain is getting warmer with climate change.\n\n'It's reached as far north as Felixstowe so any shipwreck below that latitude is threatened by it.\n\nThe Dutch merchant ship De Rooswijkcarrying chests of silver ingots, silver dollars and pieces of eight hit treacherous sandbanks in January 1740 (artist's impression pictured)\n\nThe ship, on its way to buy nutmeg and pepper in the East Indies sank, killing all on board - some 250 men, women and children. Several silver 'Pillar dollars' (pictured), minted in Mexico, have been found on the ship along with silver pieces of eight\n\n'It burrows into any wood which speeds up decay and makes the wrecks vulnerable. It attacks the timbers and wooden chests.\n\n'So it's important that we start conserving these things now to prevent any more damage.'\n\nLittle is known about the crew of the ship, skippered by Daniel Rousiers, which first sailed to what was then Batavia - modern day Indonesia - in 1737.\n\nTo recover objects (pictured), the team use a machine to carefully suck up the sand from the site, revealing buried artefacts.\n\nIt sank on the second day of its second voyage in 1740.\n\nTo recover objects, the team use a machine to carefully suck up the sand from the site, revealing buried artefacts.\n\nThree large chests have been recovered from the current excavation which may contain bullion.\n\nThe archaeologists will carefully open the chests slowly after they are X-rayed to discover what is inside, to ensure nothing might be inadvertently damaged in the process.\n\nThe divers have also recovered spoons, shoes, belt buckles, pipes, pewter tankards, glassware, ornate knife handles, and musket balls.\n\nSeveral cannons are still on the sea bed.\n\nSeveral silver 'Pillar dollars' - minted in Mexico - have been found on the ship along with silver pieces of eight.\n\nThe research team believe that some of the silver was being smuggled by sailors for their own personal trade.\n\nThe items recovered from the sea are being stored in fresh water and will be on display to the public in Ramsgate.\n\nThree large chests have been recovered from the current excavation which may contain bullion. This image shows conservation team member Elisabeth Kuiber holds a piece of eight silver coin from the Rooswijk\n\nThe divers have also recovered spoons, shoes, belt buckles, pipes, pewter tankards, glassware, ornate knife handles, and musket balls (pictured)\n\nThis image shows a pewter jug found during excavation works on the Rooswijk. Several cannons and an anchor are still on the sea bed\n\nDivers are also beginning to recover human remains from the 26-metre-long ship - bones which can be examined and tested for DNA to get insight into the lives of those on board.\n\nMark Dunkley, a marine archaeologist from Historic England explained 'With the finds that we're bringing up we're seeing how they lived on board, and now with the remains we are seeing how they died as well.'\n\nIt would be too expensive to pull the whole ship out of the sand, store and conserve it, as happened with Henry VIII's warship the Mary Rose, recovered in 1982 off the coast of Portsmouth.\n\nMr Dunkley said the shipwreck site had been monitored since it became a protected site in 2007. He said: 'Our last survey was last year when more material was exposed than ever before.'\n\nThe research team believe that some of the silver was being smuggled by sailors for their own personal trade. This image shows conservation team members Elisabeth Kuiber and Eric Nordgren with finds including musket balls and a spoon from the Rooswijk\n\nThe archaeologists will carefully open the chests slowly after they are X-rayed to discover what is inside, to ensure nothing might be inadvertently damaged in the process. This images shows pewter spoons found during excavation works\n\nDivers are also beginning to recover human remains from the 26-metre-long ship - bones which can be examined and tested for DNA to get insight into the lives of those on board. This image shows shoe parts found on the wreck\n\nResearchers in the Netherlands are combing archives for further information about the De Rooswijk.\n\nMr Dunkley said: 'There were probably some women on the ship.\n\nThey could have been 'guests of the lower deck', a term for prostitutes.\n\nHe said that in most archaeological sites are graveyards where people have died naturally.\n\nFinding the remains of healthy individuals who died in the prime of their life 'Is like an underwater Pompeii', Mr Dunkley said.\n\nResearchers in the Netherlands are combing archives for further information about the De Rooswijk. This image shows a pewter jug found on the ship\n\nThis image shows conservationist Thijs Coenen with a pewter jug he recovered from the wreck of the Dutch East India Company ship\n\nThis glass bottle was found by an international team of maritime archaeologists exploring the wreck\n\n'We've got that population at the minute that castastrophe happened.\n\n'It's very rare to find a grave and know how that person died.\n\n'Here we know everyone drowned or were crushed prior to drowning.'\n\nIn 2004, diver Ken Welling visited the wreck, and retrieved two complete chests and hundreds of silver bars.\n\nSeveral hundred Mexican silver cobs of the 1720s and early 1730s, and transitional 'klippes' that date to around 1733 have been recovered.\n\nHundreds more 'pillar dollars' have also been discovered and sold at auction.\n\nAs well as wrecked ships, in 2000 a crashed German Dornier Do-17 Z bomber, downed in 1940 during World War II was recovered from the sands.\n\nThis image shows a Find out what's happening in the world as it unfolds.\n\n(CNN)The commanding officer, executive officer and senior non-commissioned officer of the USS Fitzgerald are due to be removed from their duties for cause amid the fallout surrounding the deadly collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a cargo ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which is, we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday.Moran added that the commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, Adm. Joseph Aucoin, \"has notified them of his intent\" to detach them for cause a move likely to occur during their non-judicial punishment process, scheduled to take place Friday.While the final investigation into the collision is ongoing, Moran said: \"We do not have to have the investigation complete to start the process.\"The Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cdr. Bryce Benson, and the executive officer, Cdr. Sean Babbiit, were both sleeping, and the master chief petty officer, Brice Baldwin, was not on the bridge at the time of collision.Read MoreThe bow of the cargo ship directly struck the commander's cabin, according to the Navy's report detailing the immediate aftermath of the collision.It said Benson \"was hanging from the side of the ship\" when he was retrieved by crewmembers who were forced to use a sledgehammer, kettlebell and their bodies to break through the door and gain access to the heavily damaged cabin.Benson was medically evacuated via helicopter due to the severity of his injuries and he placed on limited duty status on July 11.\"There are a lot of sailors\" who have undergone the non-judicial punishment process and \"survived and done well,\" Moran said, but \"when you look at what happened here, it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\"While additional non-judicial punishments could be levied at the \"captain's mast\" inquiry, due to take place Friday, Moran said that Aucoin \"has already made the decision to detach for cause\" the leadership team.\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that \"clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness.\"One additional sailor has already undergone the captain's mast. Several other sailors are due to go through the process, including the people who were on watch that night.The Navy also plans to review its training and qualification procedures in the wake of the deadly collision, in which the Fitzgerald was heavily damaged. It will have to be brought back to the US for repairs.The Navy's report on the immediate aftermath provides a harrowing account of US sailors attempting to escape a rapidly flooding sleeping area that filled with water within minutes after the cargo ship's bow tore a hole in the side of the Fitzgerald. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.The report describes a chaotic scene following the collision between the Fitzgerald and the much larger cargo ship. Some sailors were thrown from their beds, while others remained asleep. Sailors ran through the sleeping area, attempting to awaken their still-sleeping crew members.\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the report said, referring to the Naval term for a bed.The crew had to move quickly to escape the area using a ladder before the sleeping area became completely flooded, with the report saying the room \"was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\"\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said.Rear Adm. Charles F. Williams wrote in the memo accompanying the report that the sailors in that sleeping area \"should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced.\"Moran said the investigation will have to be completed before any medals or awards can be adjudicated to any sailors for acts of heroism. An acting commanding officer had been assigned to the Fitzgerald following the collision, and a permanent replacement, Cdr. Garrett Miller, has been identified and is expected to take command soon.The full investigation will have to be completed in order for the Navy to assign responsibility for the collision.", "date":
