{"sim": 0.7529411911964417, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9848402", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "todayonline.com", "title": "TODAY", "id": "1197"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.todayonline.com/sites/default/files/photos/43_images/29991924.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 203, "textEnd": 209, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 667, "textEnd": 674, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 7749, "textEnd": 7756, "date": "-06-18", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.todayonline.com/world/americas/top-two-officers-navy-ship-deadly-collision-japan-are-relieved-duties", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:08:00", "title": "Top two officers on navy ship in deadly collision off Japan are relieved of duties", "uri": "711324533", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T08:08:00Z", "time": "08:08:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- About a dozen US sailors aboard a destroyer during a deadly collision off the coast of Japan in June will be punished for their roles in the accident, a senior Navy official said Thursday (Aug 17). They include the two top officers, who will be relieved of duty.\n\nThe disciplinary measures were announced as the Navy released a harrowing preliminary report on the collision between the destroyer USS Fitzgerald and a freighter that killed seven people aboard the US ship. It was one of the Navy's deadliest accidents in years.\n\nThe ship's captain, Cmdr Bryce Benson; his second in command; the senior enlisted sailor and all those on watch the night of June 17 will face potentially career-killing administrative punishments that are expected to be doled out on Friday by the head of the Navy's 7th Fleet in Japan, Vice Adm Joseph P Aucoin.\n\nThe report described in detail the moments after the collision and the rescue efforts aboard the ship.\n\nDozens of sailors who were rocked from their slumber, the report said, raced in the dark to escape from their flooding quarters. Within 90 seconds, seawater rushing through a gaping hole in the starboard hull was at first waist deep, then neck high as sailors pushed aside mattresses, wall lockers and other floating debris to clamber up a ladder to safety. The last sailor pulled from the chaos was underwater when his shipmates yanked him up.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into Cmdr Benson's stateroom, ripping open a huge hole and trapping him inside. It took five sailors, using a sledgehammer and kettlebell, 25 minutes to break down the door to his cabin to rescue the captain, who was seriously injured and hanging from the side of the ship.\n\nIn summing up the failures of the captain and his crew, the vice chief of naval operations, Adm Bill Moran, said the report made clear that \"serious mistakes were made by members of the crew.\" As the shipping lanes got more crowded that night, Adm Moran said the sailors on watch \"lost situational awareness,\" and by the time they realised their errors, it was too late to avoid a collision with the much larger freighter.\n\nWhat the report released on Thursday did not answer, and what is still under a separate ongoing investigation, is how the collision could have happened. Were lookouts on watch scanning the seas for other ships and, if so, why did they not see the 728-foot freighter, the ACX Crystal, stacked with more than 1,000 containers, bearing on the destroyer? How did radar officers on the bridge and in the combat information centre below fail to detect the freighter closing in? And why was Cmdr Benson not awakened and summoned to the bridge, as standard protocol requires, to ensure safe passage?\n\nAdm Moran said it could be weeks before the investigation is completed into the causes and culpability for the accident.\n\nCmdr Benson and the Fitzgerald's second-in-command, or executive officer, Cmdr Sean Babbitt, both of whom were asleep in their cabins when the ships collided, and the Fitzgerald's senior enlisted sailor, Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, were relieved of their duties aboard the Fitzgerald. Cmdr Benson, as well as several sailors on watch that night, will face what the military calls nonjudicial punishment.\n\nIn today's competitive Navy, the chances of these men being promoted with such black marks on their records is extremely remote.\n\nAdm Moran cautioned that as the investigation into the accident's cause proceeds, more sailors could face disciplinary action. It was not clear whether any crew members would face court-martial.\n\nThe report laid out a chilling scenario in which sailors were awakened suddenly by a loud noise and forced to evacuate amid fast-rising waters and in near-darkness.\n\nThe two ships that collided could not have been more different. The 9,000-ton, US$1.5 billion (S$2.05 billion) Fitzgerald, operating out of the Yokosuka naval base, was wrapping up a long day of training. The 29,000-ton Crystal, manned by a Filipino crew, is more than 200 feet longer than the Fitzgerald. It had been chartered by a Japanese company to take cargo from Nagoya, on Japan's central coast, to Tokyo. The Crystal was far less damaged than the Fitzgerald.\n\nWithin seconds of the collision, seawater poured through a 13-by-17-foot hole in the starboard hull, and the 505-foot Fitzgerald listed sharply to the starboard side. The ship radio room was damaged, and much of its communications gear ruined or left without power. Below decks, the crew was plunged into darkness except for red emergency lights.\n\nUS Navy ships and their crews train extensively for emergencies on board such as collisions and fires. Emergency crews responded immediately to reports of damage and trapped sailors across the ship.\n\nThe Fitzgerald had a crew of about 300 sailors, and the crisis focused on a sleeping compartment called Berthing 2, which has 42 beds in triple bunks spanning one side of the ship across to the other, two decks below the main deck.\n\nThe area also had a lounge filled with sofas, chairs, a table and a television set.\n\nOf the 42 sailors assigned to Berthing 2 at the time of collision, five were on watch and two were not aboard ship. Of the 35 remaining sailors in the crew area, 28 escaped the flooding and seven died.\n\nSome of the surviving sailors said they heard a loud noise at the time of impact. Others were thrown from their beds. Still others said they did not realise what happened and stayed in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\nWithin seconds, though, sailors were yelling, \"Water on deck! Get out!\" Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one had to be pulled from his bed and into the water before he woke up. Senior sailors checked for any who might still be in their beds.\n\nSailors told investigators that after the initial shock, they lined up calmly and walked several steps through the rushing water to climb a port side ladder and escape through a watertight hatch.\n\nBy the time the last group of sailors arrived at the bottom of the ladder, the water was up to their necks. Two sailors who had been helping others from the bottom of the ladder were eventually forced to climb the ladder as water reached the very top of the berthing compartment.\n\nOnce through the hatch, the sailors continued to search, reaching into the dark water to try to find anyone they could. From the top of the ladder, the two sailors pulled two others from the flooded compartment. Both of the rescued sailors were completely underwater when they were pulled to safety.\n\nThe last sailor to be pulled up from the murky darkness had been in the bathroom at the time of the collision and a flood of water knocked him to the floor. At one point he was pinned between the lockers floating past him and the compartment ceiling, but he was able to reach for a pipe on the ceiling to pull himself free. He made his way to the only light he could see, which was coming from the portside hatch.\n\nHe was swimming toward the hatch, the report said, \"when he was pulled from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported that when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nTwenty-seven sailors escaped Berthing 2 from the port side. One other sailor escaped from the starboard side.\n\nA Japanese coast guard helicopter lowered a rescue basket to lift the badly injured Cmdr Benson off the listing ship and whisk him to a Navy hospital in Yokosuka. Other US and Japanese military vessels and aircraft helped in the rescue effort.\n\nJust before 5am, with the flooding stabilised and operating under its own power, the Fitzgerald slowly started making its way back to port.\n\nThe next day, June 18, the bodies of the seven men who died were recovered by Navy divers from flooded spaces that had been sealed off to keep the ship from foundering, a wrenching decision by officers in the chaotic aftermath of the crash. {"sim": 0.7490196228027344, "details": {"liCnt": 6}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9808984", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "military.com", "title": "Military.com", "id": "6645"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://images02.military.com/media/equipment/uss-fitzgerald-1200x800.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 880, "textEnd": 887, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.military.com/daily-news/2017/08/17/navy-fires-3-leaders-uss-fitzgerald-wake-deadly-collision.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:12:00", "title": "Navy Fires Commander, XO from USS Fitzgerald for Fatal Collision", "uri": "711209050", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:11:00Z", "time": "21:11:00", "body": "A depiction of where the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship ACX and the damage the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer incurred. (U.S. Navy images)\n\nThe commander of the destroyer USS Fitzgerald and the executive officer have been permanently detached from the ship and face non-judicial punishment over the deadly collision in June with a container ship, the Navy announced Thursday.\n\nCmdr. Bryce Benson, commander of the Fitzgerald, and Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, the executive officer, are \"being detached for cause,\" meaning that the Navy \"has lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" Adm. Bill Moran, Vice Chief of Naval Operations, said during a press conference.\n\nVice Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, has also decided that the top enlisted sailor aboard the Fitzgerald and several other sailors on the watch crew at the time of the collision on June 17 will also face non-judicial punishment, Moran said.\n\nAucoin ruled that \"serious mistakes were made by the crew,\" Moran said.\n\nThe Fitzgerald was hit nearly broadside by the ACX Crystal cargo ship in the early morning hours of June 17 in Japanese waters. Seven sailors aboard the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer Fitzgerald were killed.\n\nThe service members, whose bodies were found in flooded berthing compartments, on Thursday were posthumously promoted.\n\nThe top enlisted sailor on the Fitzgerald was later identified as Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin. He, Benson and Babbitt were all in their berths when the collision occurred.\n\nHowever, Aucoin found that all three bore chief responsibility for the watch crew on the bridge losing \"situational awareness\" as the destroyer was proceeding at about 20 knots on a clear moonlit night in relatively calm seas, Moran said.\n\nWhen asked if the non-judicial punishment against Benson, Babbitt and Baldwin would be career ending, Moran said: \"Look at what happened here -- it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\" Moran said investigations were continuing but he declined to speculate on whether courts martial might be pursued against any of the Fitzgerald's crew.\n\nRelated content:\n\nSince the accident occurred, naval experts have pondered how a fast and agile destroyer carrying some of the world's most advanced radars and proceeding on a clear moonlit night in calm seas could have been hit nearly broadside by a slow and plodding cargo ship.\n\nThe speculation has centered on whether the bridge watch crew was either poorly trained or simply not alert. Moran said only that collisions should not happen in the U.S. Navy -- \"We got it wrong.\"\n\nA \"line of duty\" investigation released by the Navy earlier Thursday on actions following the collision gave evidence of the enormous damage inflicted on the Fitzgerald and the heroic actions of the crew in saving the ship and their fellow sailors.\n\nBerthing Area 2, two decks below the main deck where 35 sailors were sleeping in three-decker buns, was exposed to the open sea, the investigation said. The bulbous nose of the ACX Crystal had ripped a 13x17 foot hole into the side of the Fitzgerald.\n\n\"As a result, nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly,\" the investigation said. The seven sailors killed in the collision were all in Berthing 2. They were \"directly in the path of the onrushing water,\" the investigation said.\n\nThe force of the collision knocked the Fitzgerald into a 14-degree list to port before the ship rocked back violently into a seven-degree list to starboard. \"One sailor saw another knocked out of his rack by water,\" the investigation said.\n\n\"Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the investigation said.\n\nThe sailors were in water up to their necks as they scrambled to reach a ladder to safety. The last rescued sailor had been in the bathroom at the time of the crash. Other sailors \"pulled him from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported he was taking his final breath before being saved,\" the investigation said.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100, {"sim": 0.7490196228027344, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9892856", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "13newsnow.com", "title": "WVEC", "id": "2163"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/a1aabf0f6e045472f1af582af4491a057870a3a5/c=0-298-5851-3604/local/-/media/2017/08/17/USATODAY/USATODAY/636385835500656701-GTY-813430400-92328741.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 501, "textEnd": 508, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 3, "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.13newsnow.com/ext/news/nation-now/article/291/5f4KkmFkHuu0YCIks4qUwI", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:33:00", "title": "Commander and leadership of stricken destroyer Fitzgerald to be relieved for collision", "uri": "711439325", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:33:00Z", "time": "12:33:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The skipper of the USS Fitzgerald and two top sailors from the ship's leadership team will be relieved for losing \"situational awareness\" in the hours leading up to a fatal June collision that left seven sailors dead, the service's deputy chief said Thursday.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, the deputy chief of naval operations, said that Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin, head of the Navy's 7th Fleet, plans to relieve Cmdr. Bryce Benson for cause. On Thursday, the Navy released a preliminary report on the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and the freighter ACX Crystal off the coast of Japan.\n\nAbout a dozen sailors in all face some punishment, including all of the destroyer's watch. Further sanctions are possible, Moran said.\n\n\"Clearly at some point, the bridge team lost situational awareness,\" Moran said.\n\nAucoin acted swiftly because the investigation indicated serious mistakes were made by the crew, Moran said. The Navy has lost confidence in the sailors being relieved.\n\nCollisions should never happen, Moran said. \"We got it wrong.\"\n\nThe report released Thursday details the frantic efforts to account for all the sailors in the darkened, flooding ship, keep her afloat, and rescue the ship's commander who dangled outside his crumpled cabin. The harrowing moments and hours after the collision -- and the heroism that saved the lives of all but seven of the 35 sailors in Berthing 2 -- are recounted in the report.\n\nA \"loud noise\" roused some of the sailors in the Fitzgerald's Berthing 2 compartment, the accident report said. Some in the ship's sleeping and living quarters \"felt an unusual movement,\" while others slept through the crash.\n\nSeconds after the ACX Crystal plowed into the starboard side of the Navy's guided missile destroyer at 1:30 a.m., on June 17, seawater gushed through a 13-foot-by-17-foot gash, knocking some from their beds and threatening to drown all 35 sailors in the compartment.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dark of night to save their ship,\" wrote Rear Adm. C.F. Williams, commander of Carrier Strike Group Five. Williams' preliminary report looks at the injuries and deaths that resulted from the crash.\n\nThe Fitzgerald, with a crew of about 300 sailors, was about 56 nautical miles southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, at the time of the collision. The sea was calm, and the moon shone through broken clouds. The Fitzgerald was dark but for navigation lights, and red bulbs inside the ship.\n\nThe Crystal is a far larger ship at 728 feet and 29,000 tons, compared with the Fitzgerald's 505 feet and 9,000 tons. The port side of the Crystal's bow slammed into the Fitzgerald above the waterline, and the bulb-like bow below the surface crunched into the Fitzgerald near Berthing 2.\n\nBerthing 2 held 42 beds in stacks of three bunks, a bathroom, and a lounge area with sofas, chairs and a television. After the collision, \"nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald rocked violently, settling into a 7-degree list to her starboard side.\n\n\"One sailor saw another knocked out of his rack by water,\" according to the report. \"Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up.\"\n\nWithin a minute, the compartment had flooded and the water rose. Mattresses, furniture and an exercise bike floated in the aisles. The tilting ship complicated the escape, and the water was neck high by the time many had reached the ladder to climb to safety.\n\n\"You can just imagine the confusion and how difficult it was to escape Berthing Compartment 2,\" Moran said.\n\nAs the water forced them to the top of the stairs, two sailors reached into the dark water and fished two more shipmates out. The last rescued sailor had been in the bathroom at the time of the crash. The sailors \"pulled him from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported he was taking is final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nThe seven sailors who drowned were nearest the gash, \"directly in the path of the onrushing water.\"\n\nSailors rushed to seal off flooding to keep the Fitzgerald afloat as water gushed through the gaping hole. Large pipes that carry seawater to fight fires also ruptured, inundating other areas.\n\nThe Crystal slammed into Benson's cabin, crumpling his quarters. Communications outside the ship were severed. Power was lost in the front of the Fitzgerald.\n\nAfter the crash, the Fitzgerald crew changed the ship's lighting at the mast to one red light over another. That configuration, \"red over red,\" is \"the international lighting scheme that indicates a ship that is not under command,\" the report notes.\n\nBenson was in his cabin when the collision occurred, and the crash trapped him. It took five sailors swinging a sledgehammer and kettle bell and hurling their bodies against his door to break through. A junior officer and two chief petty officers yanked debris out of the cabin and crawled in.\n\n\"The skin of the ship and outer bulkhead were gone and the night sky could be seen through the hanging wires and ripped steel,\" the report says. \"The rescue team tied themselves together with a belt in order to create a makeshift harness as they retrieved (Benson), who was hanging from the side of the ship.\"\n\nA helicopter whisked him ashore to a hospital. He was treated and released the next day.\n\nThe Fitzgerald, still listing, crept back to Yokosuka. Navy divers recovered the bodies of the seven drown sailors on June 17.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Water_Resources", "wgt": 100, "id": 132, "label": William F. Moran, vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that about a dozen sailors who were aboard the USS Fitzgerald when it collided with a container ship June 17 off the coast of Japan, killing seven crew members, will face disciplinary action, including the top two officers and top enlisted sailor.\n\nMoran said most of the punishments will be delivered Friday, and the ship's captain at the time, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; his second-in-command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and senior enlisted sailor for the ship, Command Master Chief Brice A. Baldwin, will be permanently removed as leaders of the ship. He also said the sailors who were on watch in the Fitzgerald's bridge \"at some point...lost situational awareness,\" and are among those facing discipline. The investigation into whether the Fitzgerald crew is solely responsible for the crash is ongoing.\n\nMoran said investigators are still trying to determine exactly what took place right before the collision, when the container ship ripped a huge hole into the smaller Fitzgerald early in the morning. Most of the sailors were asleep when the accident occurred, and a majority of those who died were sleeping closest to where the water came rushing in, The Washington Post reports. Survivors said they had to try to escape as items like mattresses and lockers floated by in the water, and several sailors, trying to keep the ship from sinking, were forced to seal a door with other sailors still inside. {"sim": 0.7490196228027344, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9829253", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "standardrepublic.com", "title": "Standard Republic", "id": "18909"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/59966333fc7e93b43f8b4567.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 242, "textEnd": 249, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/top-two-navy-officers-booted-from-service-after-fallout-from-uss-fitzgerald-crash-near-japan-rt-america/26371.htm", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:41:00", "title": "Top two Navy officers booted from service after fallout from USS Fitzgerald crash near Japan  --  RT America - Standard Republic", "uri": "711267692", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:33:00Z", "time": "02:33:00", "body": "Around a dozen American sailors on a destroyer that collided with a freighter off the coast of Japan will now face the consequences. Two top officers will be kicked out of the Navy as a result of the crash.\n\nOn Thursday, two months after the June 17 crash, the Navy released an alarming preliminary report detailing the collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a 728-foot freighter, the ACX Crystal, which was carrying more than 1,000 containers.\n\nThe collision resulted in seven deaths and stands out as one of the Navy's deadliest accidents in years, the New York Times reported.\n\nThe ship's captain, Commander Bryce Benson, along with his second in command, Commander Sean Babbitt, were both asleep in their cabins when the crash happened.\n\nBenson, Babbitt, the senior enlisted sailor, Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin and everyone who was on watch on the night of the collision will face consequences on Friday. The penalties handed out, called nonjudicial punishments, will end their careers, according to the Navy report.\n\nThe head of the Navy's seventh fleet in Japan, Vice Admiral Joseph P. Aucoin, will deliver the sanctions to the sailors.\n\nThe Navy report describes the moments following the collision and the rescue efforts on the ship. It describes how dozens of sailors were awaken from their sleep after feeling the ship rock.\n\nThey then had to race in the dark after discovering their quarters were beginning to flood. Within 90 seconds, seawater began to rush through a gaping hole and it rose to the height of the sailors' waists.\n\nThe water rose as high as their necks, as the officers pushed aside wall lockers, mattresses and other floating debris to make it up a ladder to safety. The last sailor to make it up the ladder was pulled only after being fully submerged in the water.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into Benson's state room and ripped open a huge hole that trapped him inside. It then took five sailors using a sledgehammer and kettlebell 25 minutes to break down the door to his cabin. The captain was seriously injured and hanging from the side of the ship.\n\nThe main focus of the disaster was in a sleeping compartment called Berthing 2. Out of the 43 sailors assigned to Berthing 2 at the moment of impact, five were on watch and two were not on the ship. Of the remaining 35 sailors in the area, 28 escaped the flooding and seven died.\n\nUS Navy emergency rescue crews responded immediately when hearing of the trapped sailors on the ship.\n\nREAD MORE: US destroyer failed to respond to warnings before fatal collision - cargo ship captain\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations said the report made clear that \"serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" according to the New York Times.\n\nAs the shipping lanes got more crowded at night, Moran said the sailors who were on watch \"lost situational awareness,\" according to the Times.\n\nBy the time they realized their error, it was too late to avoid the crash with the much larger freighter.\n\nThe report released Thursday still fails to explain the separate investigation of why the crew did not see a large freighter coming towards them and how the collision happened. Admiral Moran said that it could take weeks for the investigation to be completed with regards to what caused the crash.\n\nMoran also said that as the investigation proceeds, more punishments may be meted to other sailors. It is not known at this time if any of the sailors will face a court martial.\n\nThe crew on the USS Fitzgerald, which cost $1.5 billion, was comprised of about 300 sailors. {"sim": 0.7450980544090271, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9791718", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "13newsnow.com", "title": "WVEC", "id": "2163"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://content.tegnanc.com/photo/2017/08/17/636385835500656701-GTY-813430400-92328741_1503007499614_10289176_ver1.0.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 543, "textEnd": 550, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.13newsnow.com/news/nation-world/commander-of-stricken-destroyer-relieved-after-navy-report-cites-failures/465193778", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:04:00", "title": "Leadership of stricken destroyer to be relieved for collision", "uri": "711155796", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:04:00Z", "time": "23:04:00", "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nWASHINGTON - The head of the Navy's 7th Fleet will relieve the skipper of the USS Fitzgerald and the remaining two sailors of the ship's leadership for losing \"situational awareness\" in the hours leading up to a fatal June collision that left seven sailors dead, the service's deputy chief said Thursday.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, the deputy chief of naval operations, said that Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin plans to relieve Cmdr. Bryce Benson for cause. On Thursday, the Navy released a preliminary report on the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and the freighter ACX Crystal off the coast of Japan.\n\nThe ship's entire leadership, Moran said, will be relieved, and about a dozen sailors face some punishment, including all of the destroyer's watch. Further sanctions are possible, Moran said.\n\nAucoin acted swiftly because the investigation indicated serious mistakes were made by the crew, Moran said. The Navy has lost confidence in those sailors.\n\nCollisions should never happen, Moran said. \"We got it wrong.\"\n\nA \"loud noise\" roused some of the sailors in the Fitzgerald's Berthing 2 compartment, the accident report said. Some in the ship's sleeping and living quarters \"felt an unusual movement,\" while others slept through the initial crash.\n\nSeconds after the ACX Crystal plowed into the starboard side of the Navy's guided missile destroyer at 1:30 a.m., on June 17, seawater gushed through a 13-foot-by-17-foot gash, knocking some from their beds and threatening to drown all 35 sailors in the compartment.\n\n\"Water on deck!\" sailors shouted. \"Get out!\"\n\nThe harrowing moments and hours after the collision -- and the heroism that saved the lives of all but seven of the 35 sailors in Berthing 2 -- are recounted in the report.\n\nIt details the frantic efforts to account for all the sailors in the darkened, flooding compartment, keep the ship afloat, and rescue the ship's commander who dangled outside his crumpled cabin.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dark of night to save their ship,\" wrote Rear Adm. C.F. Williams, commander of Carrier Strike Group Five. Williams' preliminary report looks at the injuries and deaths that resulted from the crash.\n\nThe Fitzgerald, with a crew of about 300 sailors, was about 56 nautical miles southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, at the time of the collision. The sea was calm, and the moon shone through broken clouds. The ship was dark but for navigation lights, and red bulbs inside.\n\nThe Crystal is a far larger ship at 728 feet and 29,000 tons, compared with the Fitzgerald's 505 feet and 9,000 tons. The port side of the Crystal's bow slammed into the Fitzgerald above the waterline, and the bulb-like bow below the surface crunched into the Fitzgerald near Berthing 2.\n\nFlooding in Berthing 2\n\nBerthing 2 held 42 beds in stacks of three bunks, a bathroom, and a lounge area. It contained a lounge with sofas, chairs and a television. After the collision, \"nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald rocked violently, settling into a 7-degree list to her starboard side.\n\n\"One sailor saw another knocked out of his rack by water,\" according to the report. \"Others began waking up shipmates who had slept through the initial impact. At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up.\"\n\nWithin a minute, the compartment had flooded and the water rose. Mattresses, furniture and an exercise bike floated in the aisles. The tilting ship complicated the escape, and the water was neck high by the time many had reached the ladder to climb to safety.\n\nAs the water forced them to the top of the stairs, two sailors reached into the dark water and fished two more shipmates out. The last rescued sailor had been in the bathroom at the time of the crash. The sailors \"pulled him from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported he was taking is final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nThe seven sailors who drowned were nearest the gash, \"directly in the path of the onrushing water.\"\n\n\u00a9 2017 USATODAY.COM\n\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Water_Resources", "wgt": 100, "id": {"sim": 0.7450980544090271, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9797112", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wsoctv.com", "title": "WSOC", "id": "497"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1678, "textEnd": 1685, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/national-news/ap-top-news/senior-officer-on-damaged-ship-to-be-relieved-of-command/594413957", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:57:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged ship to be relieved of command", "uri": "711171125", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:57:00Z", "time": "23:57:00", "body": "Adm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nIn addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment that has yet to be determined, Moran said, adding that details on those actions are to be announced Friday after they are completed.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted.\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion. That is within Japanese territorial waters. The seas were relatively calm, and visibility was unrestricted. The bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct. It commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9887752", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "news5cleveland.com", "title": "newsnet5", "id": "18317"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://sharing.newsnet5.com/sharescnn/photo/2017/08/18/S080349195_1503057385625_64442179_ver1.0_640_480.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 266, "textEnd": 273, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1469, "textEnd": 1476, "date": "2017-07-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.news5cleveland.com/news/national/uss-fitzgeralds-leaders-removed-from-their-duties-over-june-collision", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:06:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald's leaders removed from their duties over June collision", "uri": "711426350", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:06:00Z", "time": "12:06:00", "body": "The commanding officer, executive officer and senior non-commissioned officer of the USS Fitzgerald have been removed from their duties for cause amid the fallout surrounding the deadly collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a cargo ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday. The 7th Fleet also said several junior officers were relieved of duty.\n\nWhile the final investigation into the collision is ongoing, Moran said: \"We do not have to have the investigation complete to start the process.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cdr. Bryce Benson, and the executive officer, Cdr. Sean Babbiit, were both sleeping, and the master chief petty officer, Brice Baldwin, were not on the bridge at the time of the collision, according to the Navy.\n\nThe bow of the cargo ship directly struck the commander's cabin, according to the Navy's report detailing the immediate aftermath of the collision.\n\nThe report said Benson \"was hanging from the side of the ship\" when he was retrieved by crewmembers who were forced to use a sledgehammer, kettlebell and their bodies to break through the door and gain access to the heavily damaged cabin.\n\nBenson was medically evacuated via helicopter due to the severity of his injuries and he placed on limited duty status on July 11.\n\n\"There are a lot of sailors\" who have undergone the non-judicial punishment process and \"survived and done well,\" Moran said, but \"when you look at what happened here, it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\"\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that \"clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness.\"\n\nOne additional sailor has already undergone the captain's mast. Several other sailors are due to go through the process, including the people who were on watch that night.\n\nThe Navy also plans to review its training and qualification procedures in the wake of the deadly collision, in which the Fitzgerald was heavily damaged. It will have to be brought back to the US for repairs.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision that claimed the lives of seven Fitzgerald sailors, injured injured three more, and damaged both ships,\" the 7th Fleet said in a statement.\n\nThe Navy's report on the immediate aftermath provides a harrowing account of US sailors attempting to escape a rapidly flooding sleeping area that filled with water within minutes after the cargo ship's bow tore a hole in the side of the Fitzgerald. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.\n\nThe report describes a chaotic scene following the collision between the Fitzgerald and the much larger cargo ship. Some sailors were thrown from their beds, while others remained asleep. Sailors ran through the sleeping area, attempting to awaken their still-sleeping crew members.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the report said, referring to the Naval term for a bed.\n\nThe crew had to move quickly to escape the area using a ladder before the sleeping area became completely flooded, with the report saying the room \"was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\"\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said.\n\nRear Adm. Charles F. Williams wrote in the memo accompanying the report that the sailors in that sleeping area \"should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced.\"\n\nMoran said the investigation will have to be completed before any medals or awards can be adjudicated to any sailors for acts of heroism.\n\nAn acting commanding officer had been assigned to the Fitzgerald following the collision, and a permanent replacement, Cdr. Garrett Miller, has been identified and is expected to take command soon.\n\nThe full investigation will have to be completed in order for the Navy to assign responsibility for the collision.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9801912", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bangordailynews.com", "title": "The Bangor Daily News", "id": "2437"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://bdn-data.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/2017/08/42516541_H21074222-600x405.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 183, "textEnd": 196, "date": "2017-06-18", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 387, "textEnd": 394, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://bangordailynews.com/2017/08/17/news/nation/top-two-officers-other-sailors-aboard-uss-fitzgerald-to-be-disciplined-following-deadly-collision/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:50:00", "title": "Top two officers, other sailors aboard USS Fitzgerald to be disciplined following deadly collision", "uri": "711185735", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:50:00Z", "time": "00:50:00", "body": "The Arleigh Burke-class guided-missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald, damaged by colliding with a Philippine-flagged merchant vessel, is seen at the U.S. naval base in Yokosuka, Japan, on June 18, 2017.\n\nThe top two officers and the top enlisted sailor who were aboard the destroyer USS Fitzgerald are among about a dozen sailors who will face discipline following an early-morning collision June 17 that killed seven crew members, a senior Navy officer said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters at the Pentagon that the majority of the punishments will be delivered Friday where the ship is homeported in Yokosuka, Japan. One sailor received an undisclosed administrative punishment Thursday.\n\n[Former shipbuilder says quality of Bath-built USS Fitzgerald saved lives in crash]\n\nThe discipline will include likely career-ending actions against Cmdr. Bryce Benson, the ship's captain at the time, and his second in command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, Moran said. They and the senior enlisted sailor for the ship, Command Master Chief Brice Baldwin, will be removed as leaders of the ship permanently, Moran said.\n\nThe admiral said that sailors who were supposed to be on watch in the ship's bridge - its nerve center - also will be disciplined. Neither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal.\n\nThe container ship's bulbous nose ripped a 13-foot by 17-foot hole in the starboard size of the Fitzgerald, flooding one compartment where 35 sailors were inside within 90 seconds, Moran said. The ensuing flooding left disoriented sailors scrambling for their lives amid a soupy mix of personal items, electronics and mattresses, and some of the survivors were forced to seal a door with other sailors still inside in an effort to prevent the ship from sinking.\n\n[Number of missing sailors found dead as US destroyer reaches port]\n\n\"You can just imagine the confusion and how difficult it would have been to escape Berthing Compartment 2,\" Moran said.\n\nBenson's stateroom also was flattened by the collision, injuring him and leaving him incapacitated. He was eventually medically evacuated from the Fitzgerald by a Japanese helicopter.\n\nThe sailors killed included Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T. Truong Huynh, 25; Gunner's Mate 2nd Class Noe Hernandez, 26; Fire Controlman 2nd Class Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23; Personnel Specialist 1st Class Xavier Alec Martin, 24, and Firecontrolman 1st {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9807310", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2017/08/18/02/4357BFAC00000578-0-image-a-30_1503019919613.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 894, "textEnd": 901, "date": "-06-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2197, "textEnd": 2210, "date": "2017-06-18", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4801306/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:52:00", "title": "Captain, two others, in deadly USS Fitzgerald crash removed from duty", "uri": "711203824", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:52:00Z", "time": "01:52:00", "body": "The highest ranking naval leaders who were aboard the USS Fitzgerald when the ship crashed in June off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, said Thursday that the ship's captain Cmdr. Bryce Benson and executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt will be relieved of their command.\n\nAdditionally Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, the ship's command master chief is being removed. Nearly a dozen other crew members face punishment.\n\nLeft to right: Executive officer Cmrd. Sean Babbitt, Captain Bryce Benson and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, are all removed from duty after the deadly crash of the USS Fitzgerald, with a dozen more crew members expected to be punished\n\nDamage is seen on the guided missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald off the Shimoda coast, after it collided with a Philippine-flagged container ship on June 17\n\nPictured, the damaged Filipino container vessel ACX Crystal after the crash\n\nThe warship USS Fitzgerald crashed into Filipino cargo ship ACX Crystal off the coast of Honshu, on June 17, claiming the lives of seven American sailors.\n\n'Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,' Moran said, adding the 'bridge team' or sailors responsible for keeping watch on the bridge to make sure the ship is safe 'lost situational awareness.'\n\nThe sailors were unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the container ship was spotted.\n\nSeven US Navy sailors were killed in the collision. They are (top row, left to right) Fire Controlman 2nd Class Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23, from Chula Vista, CA; Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19, from Palmyra, VA; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T Truong Huynh, 25, from Oakville, CT; and Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25, from San Diego, CA. Bottom row (left to right Fire Controlman 1st Class Gary Leo Rehm Jr., from Elyria, OH; Personnel Specialist 1st Class Xavier Alec Martin, 24, from Halethorpe, MD; and Gunner's Mate 2nd Class Noe Hernandez, 26, from Weslaco, TX\n\nDamage to the guided missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald is seen as the vessel is berthed at its mother port in Yokosuka, southwest of Tokyo, on June 18, 2017\n\nSeparately, the Navy released the results of a review of events that took place aboard the ship after the collision, focusing on the crew's efforts to control damage, save lives and keep the ship afloat.\n\nThe US Navy faced embarrassing questions in June over how one of their advanced $1.5bn missile destroyer was struck in near perfect visibility.\n\nSeas were calm and visibility was unrestricted when the crash occurred in the predawn hours.\n\nThe bow of the container ship, the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal, slammed into the Fitzgerald's right side above the waterline, quickly flooding several areas inside the ship, including a berthing, or sleeping, area.\n\n'Heroic efforts prevented the flooding from catastrophically spreading which could have caused the ship to founder or sink,' said Vice Admiral Aucoin at a press conference the day after the collision.\n\nThe seven who died are: Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23; Xavier Alex Martin, 24; Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Rehm Jr, 37; Ngoc T Truong Huynh, 25; and Noe Hernandez, 26.\n\nThe US Navy faced embarrassing questions over how one of their advanced $1.5bn warships was struck in near perfect visibility\n\nDevastating damage. The Navy said the commanding officer of the warship that lost seven sailors in the collision will be relieved of command\n\nThe Fitzgerald's captain, Bryce Benson, was asleep at the time of the collision and it remains unclear whether the crew called the commanding officer to the bridge.\n\nThe crash left a huge hole in the hull of the Fitzgerald's starboard side and water poured into the area where sailors slept.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2 at the time, 28 escaped. Seven drowned.\n\nThe collision knocked out external communications and cut power in the forward portion of the ship.\n\nThe Navy review of what happened aboard the ship following the collision found that the seven deaths could not be blamed on misconduct.\n\nIt commended the response by the ship's crew, singling out two sailors for taking extra steps to help other out of the flooded berthing space - actions that it said likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\n\n'No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,' the review said.\n\nThe report said that although some in Berthing 2 heard a loud noise at the time of the collision or were thrown from their beds by the force of the impact, some did not realize what had happened and remained in bed. Some remained asleep.\n\n'At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,' it said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9859210", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "newsline.com", "title": "Newsline", "id": "18859"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://newsline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/img.rt_.com59966333fc7e93b43f8b4567-ea10378133f32795d0b731f406bb11bc0542c52d.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 242, "textEnd": 249, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://newsline.com/top-two-navy-officers-booted-from-service-after-fallout-from-uss-fitzgerald-crash-near-japan/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:15:00", "title": "Top two Navy officers booted from service after fallout from USS Fitzgerald crash near Japan - Newsline", "uri": "711352209", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:46:00Z", "time": "02:46:00", "body": "Around a dozen American sailors on a destroyer that collided with a freighter off the coast of Japan will now face the consequences. Two top officers will be kicked out of the Navy as a result of the crash.\n\nOn Thursday, two months after the June 17 crash, the Navy released an alarming preliminary report detailing the collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a 728-foot freighter, the ACX Crystal, which was carrying more than 1,000 containers.\n\nThe collision resulted in seven deaths and stands out as one of the Navy's deadliest accidents in years, the New York Times reported.\n\nThe ship's captain, Commander Bryce Benson, along with his second in command, Commander Sean Babbitt, were both asleep in their cabins when the crash happened.\n\nBenson, Babbitt, the senior enlisted sailor, Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin and everyone who was on watch on the night of the collision will face consequences on Friday. The penalties handed out, called nonjudicial punishments, will end their careers, according to the Navy report.\n\nThe head of the Navy's seventh fleet in Japan, Vice Admiral Joseph P. Aucoin, will deliver the sanctions to the sailors.\n\nThe Navy report describes the moments following the collision and the rescue efforts on the ship. It describes how dozens of sailors were awaken from their sleep after feeling the ship rock.\n\nThey then had to race in the dark after discovering their quarters were beginning to flood. Within 90 seconds, seawater began to rush through a gaping hole and it rose to the height of the sailors' waists.\n\nThe water rose as high as their necks, as the officers pushed aside wall lockers, mattresses and other floating debris to make it up a ladder to safety. The last sailor to make it up the ladder was pulled only after being fully submerged in the water.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into Benson's state room and ripped open a huge hole that trapped him inside. It then took five sailors using a sledgehammer and kettlebell 25 minutes to break down the door to his cabin. The captain was seriously injured and hanging from the side of the ship.\n\nThe main focus of the disaster was in a sleeping compartment called Berthing 2. Out of the 43 sailors assigned to Berthing 2 at the moment of impact, five were on watch and two were not on the ship. Of the remaining 35 sailors in the area, 28 escaped the flooding and seven died.\n\nUS Navy emergency rescue crews responded immediately when hearing of the trapped sailors on the ship.\n\nREAD MORE: US destroyer failed to respond to warnings before fatal collision - cargo ship captain\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations said the report made clear that \"serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" according to the New York Times.\n\nAs the shipping lanes got more crowded at night, Moran said the sailors who were on watch \"lost situational awareness,\" according to the Times.\n\nBy the time they realized their error, it was too late to avoid the crash with the much larger freighter.\n\nThe report released Thursday still fails to explain the separate investigation of why the crew did not see a large freighter coming towards them and how the collision happened. Admiral Moran said that it could take weeks for the investigation to be completed with regards to what caused the crash.\n\nMoran also said that as the investigation proceeds, more punishments may be meted to other sailors. It is not known at this time if any of the sailors will face a court martial.\n\nThe crew on the USS Fitzgerald, which cost $1.5 billion, was comprised of about 300 sailors. It was operating from Yokosuka naval base in Japan.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Topic", "wgt": 100, "id": 653, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Topic"}], Two top officers will be kicked out of the Navy as a result of the crash.\n\nOn Thursday, two months after the June 17 crash, the Navy released an alarming preliminary report detailing the collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a 728-foot freighter, the ACX Crystal, which was carrying more than 1,000 containers.\n\nThe collision resulted in seven deaths and stands out as one of the Navy's deadliest accidents in years, the New York Times reported.\n\nThe ship's captain, Commander Bryce Benson, along with his second in command, Commander Sean Babbitt, were both asleep in their cabins when the crash happened.\n\nBenson, Babbitt, the senior enlisted sailor, Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin and everyone who was on watch on the night of the collision will face consequences on Friday. The penalties handed out, called nonjudicial punishments, will end their careers, according to the Navy report.\n\nThe head of the Navy's seventh fleet in Japan, Vice Admiral Joseph P. Aucoin, will deliver the sanctions to the sailors.\n\nThe Navy report describes the moments following the collision and the rescue efforts on the ship. It describes how dozens of sailors were awaken from their sleep after feeling the ship rock.\n\nThey then had to race in the dark after discovering their quarters were beginning to flood. Within 90 seconds, seawater began to rush through a gaping hole and it rose to the height of the sailors' waists.\n\nThe water rose as high as their necks, as the officers pushed aside wall lockers, mattresses and other floating debris to make it up a ladder to safety. The last sailor to make it up the ladder was pulled only after being fully submerged in the water.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into Benson's state room and ripped open a huge hole that trapped him inside. It then took five sailors using a sledgehammer and kettlebell 25 minutes to break down the door to his cabin. The captain was seriously injured and hanging from the side of the ship.\n\nThe main focus of the disaster was in a sleeping compartment called Berthing 2. Out of the 43 sailors assigned to Berthing 2 at the moment of impact, five were on watch and two were not on the ship. {"sim": 0.7372549176216125, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9887198", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "gantdaily.com", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "id": "537"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://gantdaily.com/images/gant-og-logo.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 266, "textEnd": 273, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1469, "textEnd": 1476, "date": "2017-07-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/18/uss-fitzgeralds-leadership-removed-from-their-duties-over-june-collision/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:02:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald's leadership removed from their duties over June collision", "uri": "711424739", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:02:00Z", "time": "12:02:00", "body": "The commanding officer, executive officer and senior non-commissioned officer of the USS Fitzgerald have been removed from their duties for cause amid the fallout surrounding the deadly collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a cargo ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday. The 7th Fleet also said several junior officers were relieved of duty.\n\nWhile the final investigation into the collision is ongoing, Moran said: \"We do not have to have the investigation complete to start the process.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cdr. Bryce Benson, and the executive officer, Cdr. Sean Babbiit, were both sleeping, and the master chief petty officer, Brice Baldwin, were not on the bridge at the time of the collision, according to the Navy.\n\nThe bow of the cargo ship directly struck the commander's cabin, according to the Navy's report detailing the immediate aftermath of the collision.\n\nThe report said Benson \"was hanging from the side of the ship\" when he was retrieved by crewmembers who were forced to use a sledgehammer, kettlebell and their bodies to break through the door and gain access to the heavily damaged cabin.\n\nBenson was medically evacuated via helicopter due to the severity of his injuries and he placed on limited duty status on July 11.\n\n\"There are a lot of sailors\" who have undergone the non-judicial punishment process and \"survived and done well,\" Moran said, but \"when you look at what happened here, it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\"\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that \"clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness.\"\n\nOne additional sailor has already undergone the captain's mast. Several other sailors are due to go through the process, including the people who were on watch that night.\n\nThe Navy also plans to review its training and qualification procedures in the wake of the deadly collision, in which the Fitzgerald was heavily damaged. It will have to be brought back to the US for repairs.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision that claimed the lives of seven Fitzgerald sailors, injured injured three more, and damaged both ships,\" the 7th Fleet said in a statement.\n\nThe Navy's report on the immediate aftermath provides a harrowing account of US sailors attempting to escape a rapidly flooding sleeping area that filled with water within minutes after the cargo ship's bow tore a hole in the side of the Fitzgerald. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.\n\nThe report describes a chaotic scene following the collision between the Fitzgerald and the much larger cargo ship. Some sailors were thrown from their beds, while others remained asleep. Sailors ran through the sleeping area, attempting to awaken their still-sleeping crew members.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the report said, referring to the Naval term for a bed.\n\nThe crew had to move quickly to escape the area using a ladder before the sleeping area became completely flooded, with the report saying the room \"was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\"\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said.\n\nRear Adm. Charles F. Williams wrote in the memo accompanying the report that the sailors in that sleeping area \"should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced.\"\n\nMoran said the investigation will have to be completed before any medals or awards can be adjudicated to any sailors for acts of heroism.\n\nAn acting commanding officer had been assigned to the Fitzgerald following the collision, and a permanent replacement, Cdr. Garrett Miller, has been identified and is expected to take command soon.\n\nThe full investigation will have to be completed in order for the Navy to assign responsibility for the collision.", "2017-08-17T22:42:00Z", "time": "22:42:00", "body": "The commander of a US Navy ship that collided with a Philippine-flagged cargo ship in the Sea of Japan, killing seven American seamen, will be punished along with several other sailors, a senior admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, said among those to be disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nSeven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17.\n\nVice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet which is based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest will be notified by the end of Friday.\n\nMoran said the disciplinary moves are all \"initial accountability actions,\" meaning the sailors could face further punishments depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes.\n\n\"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\nAged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping berths a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the {"sim": 0.7333333492279053, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9828061", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wearecentralpa.com", "title": "WEARECENTRALPA", "id": "253"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://static.lakana.com/nxsglobal/feedsite/photo/2017/06/19/Fitzgerald%20and%20tug_22947909_ver1.0_640_360.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 278, "textEnd": 285, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1691, "textEnd": 1698, "date": "2017-07-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wearecentralpa.com/news/national/uss-fitzgeralds-leadership-to-be-removed/792214544", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:30:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald's leadership to be removed", "uri": "711264210", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:30:00Z", "time": "05:30:00", "body": "(CNN) - The commanding officer, executive officer and senior non-commissioned officer of the USS Fitzgerald are due to be removed from their duties for cause amid the fallout surrounding the deadly collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a cargo ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which is, we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday.\n\nMoran added that the commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, Adm. Joseph Aucoin, \"has notified them of his intent\" to detach them for cause a move likely to occur during their non-judicial punishment process, scheduled to take place Friday.\n\nWhile the final investigation into the collision is ongoing, Moran said: \"We do not have to have the investigation complete to start the process.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cdr. Bryce Benson, and the executive officer, Cdr. Sean Babbiit, were both sleeping, and the master chief petty officer, Brice Baldwin, was not on the bridge at the time of collision, according to the Navy.\n\nThe bow of the cargo ship directly struck the commander's cabin, according to the Navy's report detailing the immediate aftermath of the collision.\n\nIt said Benson \"was hanging from the side of the ship\" when he was retrieved by crewmembers who were forced to use a sledgehammer, kettlebell and their bodies to break through the door and gain access to the heavily damaged cabin.\n\nBenson was medically evacuated via helicopter due to the severity of his injuries and he placed on limited duty status on July 11.\n\n\"There are a lot of sailors\" who have undergone the non-judicial punishment process and \"survived and done well,\" Moran said, but \"when you look at what happened here, it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\"\n\nWhile additional non-judicial punishments could be levied at the \"captain's mast\" inquiry, due to take place Friday, Moran said that Aucoin \"has already made the decision to detach for cause\" the leadership team.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that \"clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness.\"\n\nOne additional sailor has already undergone the captain's mast. Several other sailors are due to go through the process, including the people who were on watch that night.\n\nThe Navy also plans to review its training and qualification procedures in the wake of the deadly collision, in which the Fitzgerald was heavily damaged. It will have to be brought back to the US for repairs.\n\nThe Navy's report on the immediate aftermath provides a harrowing account of US sailors attempting to escape a rapidly flooding sleeping area that filled with water within minutes after the cargo ship's bow tore a hole in the side of the Fitzgerald. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.\n\nThe report describes a chaotic scene following the collision between the Fitzgerald and the much larger cargo ship. Some sailors were thrown from their beds, while others remained asleep. Sailors ran through the sleeping area, attempting to awaken their still-sleeping crew members.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the report said, referring to the Naval term for a bed.\n\nThe crew had to move quickly to escape the area using a ladder before the sleeping area became completely flooded, with the report saying the room \"was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\"\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said.\n\nRear Adm. Charles F. Williams wrote in the memo accompanying the report that the sailors in that sleeping area \"should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced.\"\n\nMoran said the investigation will have to be completed before any medals or awards can be adjudicated to any sailors for acts of heroism.\n\nAn acting commanding officer had been assigned to the Fitzgerald following the collision, and a permanent replacement, Cdr. Garrett Miller, has been identified and is expected to take command soon.\n\nThe full investigation will have to be completed in order for the Navy to assign responsibility for the collision.", {"sim": 0.7333333492279053, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9796145", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "gantdaily.com", "title": "Clearfield Gant Daily", "id": "537"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://gantdaily.com/images/gant-og-logo.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 270, "textEnd": 277, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1660, "textEnd": 1667, "date": "2017-07-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/17/uss-fitzgeralds-leadership-to-be-removed-from-their-duties-over-june-collision/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:46:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald's leadership to be removed from their duties over June collision", "uri": "711167978", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:46:00Z", "time": "23:46:00", "body": "The commanding officer, executive officer and senior non-commissioned officer of the USS Fitzgerald are due to be removed from their duties for cause amid the fallout surrounding the deadly collision between the USS Fitzgerald and a cargo ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which is, we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday.\n\nMoran added that the commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, Adm. Joseph Aucoin, \"has notified them of his intent\" to detach them for cause a move likely to occur during their non-judicial punishment process, scheduled to take place Friday.\n\nWhile the final investigation into the collision is ongoing, Moran said: \"We do not have to have the investigation complete to start the process.\"\n\nThe Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cdr. Bryce Benson, and the executive officer, Cdr. Sean Babbiit, were both sleeping, and the master chief petty officer, Brice Baldwin, was not on the bridge at the time of collision.\n\nThe bow of the cargo ship directly struck the commander's cabin, according to the Navy's report detailing the immediate aftermath of the collision.\n\nIt said Benson \"was hanging from the side of the ship\" when he was retrieved by crewmembers who were forced to use a sledgehammer, kettlebell and their bodies to break through the door and gain access to the heavily damaged cabin.\n\nBenson was medically evacuated via helicopter due to the severity of his injuries and he placed on limited duty status on July 11.\n\n\"There are a lot of sailors\" who have undergone the non-judicial punishment process and \"survived and done well,\" Moran said, but \"when you look at what happened here, it's going to be pretty hard to recover from this.\"\n\nWhile additional non-judicial punishments could be levied at the \"captain's mast\" inquiry, due to take place Friday, Moran said that Aucoin \"has already made the decision to detach for cause\" the leadership team.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that \"clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness.\"\n\nOne additional sailor has already undergone the captain's mast. Several other sailors are due to go through the process, including the people who were on watch that night.\n\nThe Navy also plans to review its training and qualification procedures in the wake of the deadly collision, in which the Fitzgerald was heavily damaged. It will have to be brought back to the US for repairs.\n\nThe Navy's report on the immediate aftermath provides a harrowing account of US sailors attempting to escape a rapidly flooding sleeping area that filled with water within minutes after the cargo ship's bow tore a hole in the side of the Fitzgerald. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.\n\nThe report describes a chaotic scene following the collision between the Fitzgerald and the much larger cargo ship. Some sailors were thrown from their beds, while others remained asleep. Sailors ran through the sleeping area, attempting to awaken their still-sleeping crew members.\n\n\"At least one sailor had to be pulled from his rack and into the water before he woke up,\" the report said, referring to the Naval term for a bed.\n\nThe crew had to move quickly to escape the area using a ladder before the sleeping area became completely flooded, with the report saying the room \"was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\"\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said.\n\nRear Adm. Charles F. Williams wrote in the memo accompanying the report that the sailors in that sleeping area \"should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced.\"\n\nMoran said the investigation will have to be completed before any medals or awards can be adjudicated to any sailors for acts of heroism.\n\nAn acting commanding officer had been assigned to the Fitzgerald following the collision, and a permanent replacement, Cdr. Garrett Miller, has been identified and is expected to take command soon.\n\nThe full investigation will have to be completed in order for the Navy to assign responsibility for the collision.", {"sim": 0.7333333492279053, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9803215", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "title": "NBC News", "id": "1630"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://media3.s-nbcnews.com/j/newscms/2017_33/2124131/170817-uss-fitzgerald-ac-732p_1ba0c2e23efc0d8296b48081606fbb06.nbcnews-fp-1200-800.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1593, "textEnd": 1600, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/navy-punishes-leadership-uss-fitzgerald-following-deadly-collision-japan-n793746", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:06:00", "title": "Navy punishes leadership of USS Fitzgerald following deadly collision", "uri": "711189797", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:06:00Z", "time": "01:06:00", "body": "The Navy on Thursday announced punishments for the leadership of the USS Fitzgerald, a destroyer that crashed into a merchant ship in Japanese waters in June leaving seven sailors dead.\n\nThe ship's commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted officer were all relieved of their responsibilities aboard the ship, Navy officials said.\n\nThe admiral of the 7th Fleet felt that \"serious mistakes were made by the crew\" of the Fitzgerald during the June collision with a Philippine container ship that led to the death of seven sailors, according to Admiral William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\nHe said \"the bridge team\" -- the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe -- had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted, according to the Associated Press.\n\nAll three of the ship's leaders will face administrative action at a so-called \"Captain's Mast\" meeting on Friday in Japan, officials said. Additionally, up to a dozen other sailors will face non-judicial punishment.\n\nWhile not an admission of guilt for the June accident, the administrative action is a strong indication that the U.S. Navy was at fault for the collision with the ACX Crystal, a Philippines-registered cargo ship.\n\nRelated: Bodies of 7 Missing U.S. Sailors Found in Damaged Destroyer\n\nTwo other naval investigations continue into the crash, where the Navy destaroyer collided with the merchant ship southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, in the early hours of June 17.\n\nThe bodies of the sailors were found in flooded compartments, the U.S. 7th Fleet said the following day.\n\nThose seven sailors were posthumously promoted on Wednesday. Twenty-eight other sailors were able to escape.\n\nA Navy review of the incident found that the deaths could not be blamed on misconduct and commended the response of the ship's crew following the collision, according to the AP.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation,\" the review said.\n\nThe birthing cabin of the ship flooded within 90 seconds of impact and many sailors behaved heroically to save the ship from sinking. The captain, at one point, was hanging onto the side of the ship and had to be rescued by the crew. His cabin was directly impacted by the collision with the cargo ship.\n\n\"They had to fight the ship to keep it above the surface. So it was traumatic,\" U.S. 7th Fleet commander Vice Admiral Joseph P. Aucoin said at a press conference at the time, \"I can't tell you how proud I am of the crew for what they did to save the ship,\" he said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri":
