{"sim": 0.729411780834198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9818222", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 355, "textEnd": 361, "date": "2017-08-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1325, "textEnd": 1332, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/u-s-navy-citing-poor-seamanship-removes-commanders-of-warship-in-deadly-crash/articleshow/60112991.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:56:00", "title": "U.S. Navy, citing poor seamanship, removes commanders of warship in deadly crash - Times of India", "uri": "711234492", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T03:56:00Z", "time": "03:56:00", "body": "* Commanders of U.S. warship removed after cargo ship collision\n\n* Seven sailors killed in June collision\n\n* Punishments are first public admission of crew mistakes\n\n* Sailors rescued from flooded berthing compartment (Recasts throughout with statement from U.S. Seventh Fleet, commanders relieved of duty)\n\nBy Idrees Ali and Tim Kelly\n\nWASHINGTON/TOKYO, Aug 17 (Reuters) - The U.S. Navy has removed the two senior officers and the senior enlisted sailor on a U.S. warship that almost sank off the coast of Japan in June after it was struck by a Philippine container ship, the Navy said on Friday.\n\nMultiple investigations have yet to apportion blame for the accident that killed seven U.S. sailors aboard the guided missile destroyer the USS Fitzgerald.\n\nHowever, the punishments are the first public admission by the U.S. Navy that mistakes by the crew contributed to the deadliest incident on a U.S. warship since Islamist extremists bombed the USS Cole in Yemen's Aden harbour in 2000.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship. Within Fitzgerald, flawed watch stander teamwork and inadequate leadership contributed to the collision,\" the U.S. Seventh Fleet said in a media release.\n\nIn the first detailed account from one of those directly involved in the collision in the early hours of June 17, the captain of the cargo ship the ACX Crystal said in a report seen by Reuters his crew signalled the Fitzgerald with flashing lights around 10 minutes before the collision. The Fitzgerald did not respond or alter course, it said..\n\nThe commercial vessel had the right-of-way under maritime rules and the Fitzgerald, which was hit on the starboard side, was likely at fault.\n\nSeveral U.S. and Japanese investigations are still under way into how the Fitzgerald and the much larger ACX Crystal collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nOne pertinent question, said two naval officers who spoke on condition of anonymity, is what was happening at the time in the Fitzgerald's Combat Information Center, where crew members monitor radar that should have detected the approach of a 30,000-ton cargo vessel.\n\nCommander Bryce Benson was relieved \"due to a loss of confidence in his ability to lead\", the Seventh Fleet said.\n\nCommander Sean Babbitt and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin \"contributed to the lack of watch stander preparedness and readiness that was evident in the events leading up to the collision\", it said.\n\nSeveral other junior officers have also been relieved, with administrative action taken against other members of the ship's watch teams.\n\n\"SERIOUS MISTAKES\"\n\nAdmiral Bill Moran, deputy chief of naval operations, told a media briefing earlier in Washington that about nine sailors would face administrative punishments.\n\n\"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew, and there was no benefit to waiting on taking accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nAn official report released on Thursday contained dramatic accounts of what happened when the freighter hit the Fitzgerald.\n\nThe collision, at 1:30 a.m. local time, tore a gash below the Fitzgerald's waterline and sent water pouring into the warship, the report said.\n\n\"Water on deck,\" sailors in a berthing area started yelling. \"Get out,\" they shouted as mattresses, furniture, and even an exercise bicycle began to float.\n\nThe berthing was completely flooded within 60 seconds, although more than two dozen of the 35 sailors in it escaped. The last sailor to be rescued was in the bathroom at the time of the collision.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him, ... at one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free,\" the report said.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the foot of the ladder in the compartment to help others escape.\n\n\"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates,\" the report said.\n\nBenson was trapped in his cabin and five sailors used a sledgehammer to break through the door.\n\n\"Even after the door was open, there was a large amount of debris and furniture against the door, preventing anyone from entering or exiting easily,\" the report said.\n\nThe sailors tied themselves to each other with a belt and rescued Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship. (Reporting by Idrees Ali in WASHINGTON and Tim Kelly in TOKYO; Editing by Yara Bayoumy, John Walcott, Leslie Adler and Paul Tait)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. {"sim": 0.7254902124404907, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9811897", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "newser.com", "title": "Newser", "id": "851"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://img2-azcdn.newser.com/image/1137891-12-20170817202627.jpeg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1484, "textEnd": 1491, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.newser.com/story/247376/sr-officer-on-damaged-ship-to-be-relieved-of-command.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:47:00", "title": "US Navy Announces Punishments in USS Fitzgerald Collision", "uri": "711217688", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:47:00Z", "time": "02:47:00", "body": "(Newser) - The captain of a Navy warship that lost seven sailors in a collision with a commercial container ship in June will be relieved of command and nearly a dozen others face punishment, the vice chief of naval operations said Thursday. The AP reports Adm. William Moran told reporters the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmrd. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin. The actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said. In addition, nearly a dozen face non-judicial punishment yet to be determined, Moran said.\n\nMoran said the actions are to be taken shortly, although the Navy's investigation into how and why the USS Fitzgerald collided with the container ship in June has not yet been completed. \"Serious mistakes were made by members of the crew,\" Moran said, adding that he could not fully detail those mistakes because the investigation is ongoing. He said \"the bridge team,\" or the sailors responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge to ensure it remains safe, had \"lost situational awareness,\" which left them unable to respond quickly enough to avoid the disaster once the oncoming container ship was spotted. The crash occurred in the pre-dawn hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan in an accident-prone area known for congestion.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": relieved of duty following his ship's collision with a Philippine cargo vessel off the coast of Japan in June, resulting in the death of seven sailors.\n\nVice Chief of Naval Operations Admiral Bill Moran said that several officials from the USS Fitzgerald will be relieved of duty, including its senior enlisted sailor, executive officer and commanding officers.\n\nMoran told reporters, \"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which [means] we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship.\"\n\n\u00a9 AP Photo/ Eugene HoshikoJapan Nears Completion of USS Fitzgerald Crash Probe, US Declines to Help\n\nOverall, a dozen sailors will face administrative punishment for the affair.\n\nAround 1:30 a.m. local time on June 17, the Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal 56 miles off the coast of Honshu, Japan, in a busy shipping route, drowning seven sailors aged 19 to 37 who were in their sleeping berths at the time of the collision.\n\nOne sailor has been notified of their punishment by Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, head of the Navy's Japan-based 7th Fleet with the rest to be notified by the end of the week.\n\nMoran said, \"If it's clear to [Aucoin] that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions.\" The findings of ongoing probes may result in additional punishments in the future, he added.\n\n\u00a9 NHK TVACX Crystal Owners May Be Liable for $2 Billion After USS Fitzgerald Crash\n\nThe \"heroic\" actions sailors took to save their shipmates were lauded by investigators. Accord to a Navy report, the ship's commanding officer, Bryce Benson, was trapped and injured when the Crystal struck his cabin. Other sailors had to use a sledgehammer to break his door open and retrieve the officer as he was \"hanging from the side of the ship.\"\n\nSome of the rescues were very close calls. One sailor who was rescued just before drowning recalling that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and [had] breathed in water.\"\n\nThis incident marks the of the stricken destroyer USS Fitzgerald will be disciplined following a June 17, collision off the Sea of Japan that killed seven members of the crew, a senior Navy official said Thursday.\n\nThe Navy may remove from duty the commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailors on the Fitzgerald for mistakes that led to the crash, Admiral William Moran, vice chief of naval operations, told reporters at the Pentagon, according to media reports.\n\nAlmost a dozen sailors, including those who critically stood watch in the ship's bridge, will face discipline, and the majority of the punishments will be announced Friday, Moran said.\n\nHe said the bridge team \"lost situational awareness\" before the 505-foot (153-meter), 9,000-ton destroyer was struck by MV ACX Crystal, a 29,000-ton Philippine-flagged container ship.\n\nIt was not clear whether any sailor would stand trial at a court-martial.\n\nA Navy report unveiled late Thursday showed that the collision at 01.20 a.m. caught many of the crew members sleeping, and resulted in one of the berthings housing 35 sailors being submerged within a minute.\n\nThe crew shouted \"water on deck\" and \"get out\", according to the report, as they tried to make their way out fighting waters and floating furniture.\n\nTwo sailors waited at the foot of the compartment's ladder to help the others evacuate, the {"sim": 0.7176470756530762, "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9788319", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "title": "The New York Times", "id": "91"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/08/18/us/18dc-navy1/18dc-navy1-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/world/asia/fitzgerald-collision-investigation.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:34:00", "title": "Top Two Officers on Navy Ship in Deadly Collision Off Japan to Be Relieved of Duties", "uri": "711145908", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:34:00Z", "time": "22:34:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Navy plans to relieve the two top officers and the senior enlisted sailor of a destroyer that collided with a freighter off the coast of Japan in June, killing seven sailors in one of the sea service's deadliest accidents in years.\n\nThe head of the Navy's Seventh Fleet, Vice Adm. Joseph P. Aucoin, was expected to take the action on Friday in Japan, the vice chief of naval operations, Adm. Bill Moran, told reporters on Thursday.\n\nAbout a dozen sailors over all face career-killing administrative actions as a result of the accident, Admiral Moran said at a briefing at the Pentagon.\n\nA preliminary report into the accident released by the Navy on Thursday describes in harrowing detail the immediate aftermath of the collision and the rescue efforts aboard the Fitzgerald. The ship's routine cruise through familiar, if crowded seas, ended in the most deadly Navy accident in years.\n\nDozens of sailors rocked from their slumber raced against time to escape up a ladder from their flooding quarters. The rushing water was at first waist high, then neck high as sailors pushed aside mattresses, wall lockers other floating debris to clamber up a ladder to safety. The last sailor pulled from the chaos was underwater when his shipmates yanked him up.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into the stateroom of the ship's captain, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, ripping open a huge hole and trapping him inside. (Mass Communication Specialist 1st Class Peter Burghart/U.S. Navy photo via AP) SEBA HSLC/ AHM Class 10 compartment results 2017 declared, check result online at result.seba.co.in, sebaonline.orgVishal Sikka resigns as MD and CEO of InfosysAmit Shah resigns as MLA, says Congress will be reduced to half in next polls\n\nThe commander of a US Navy ship that collided with a Philippine-flagged cargo ship off Japan, killing seven American seamen, will be relieved of duty and several other sailors face punishment, a senior admiral said Thursday. Among those being disciplined from the crew of the USS Fitzgerald are its commanding officer, executive officer and senior enlisted sailor, who will all be relieved of their duties aboard the ship, said Admiral Bill Moran, the vice chief of naval operations.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which (means) we've lost trust and confidence for their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship,\" Moran told reporters.\n\nSeven sailors drowned in their sleeping berth when the USS Fitzgerald collided with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal in a busy shipping channel off Japan's coast early on June 17. Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed by today. About a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total.\n\nVice Admiral Joseph Aucoin, who heads the Navy's 7th Fleet, based in Yokosuka, Japan has notified one sailor of his or her punishment and the rest would likely be informed by today. About a dozen sailors are expected to be disciplined in total. \"If it's clear to (Aucoin) that some members of that crew should no longer be doing this line of work, it's time to move them on, it's time to take accountability actions,\" Moran said.\n\nMoran said the sailors could face further punishments later one, depending on the outcome of various ongoing probes. \"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\nAged 19 to 37, the drowned seamen were found by divers in flooded sleeping quarters a day after the collision tore a huge gash in the side of the Fitzgerald. Moran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into what happened in the immediate aftermath of the crash.\n\nMoran spoke to Pentagon reporters just as the Navy released findings from a preliminary inquiry into what happened in the immediate aftermath of the crash. The report found that all seven victims died in the line of duty and their deaths were not due to any misconduct on their part.\n\nInvestigators praised the quick-thinking and \"heroic\" actions of sailors who worked to save shipmates, one of whom had to be dragged from his bunk in a flooding sleeping area as waters quickly rose. One sailor who was rescued moments before he would have drowned reported that \"when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nAdditionally, the report describes how the ship's commanding officer was injured when the merchant ship Crystal struck his cabin, trapping him inside. Fellow sailors had to smash and pry his door open before retrieving the commander, who was \"hanging from the side of the ship. The officer was eventually medically evacuated by helicopter.\n\nMoran praised the actions of the drowned sailors. The last of them to be buried was laid to rest on Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery outside Washington.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App", "date": "2017-08-18", Bryce Benson, the ship's captain at the time, and his second in command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, Moran said. Neither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal.\n\nThe container ship's bulbous nose ripped a 13-by-17-foot hole in the starboard size of the Fitzgerald, flooding one compartment where 35 sailors were inside within 90 seconds, Moran said. {"sim": 0.6980392336845398, "details": {"liCnt": 5}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9808994", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "title": "Stars and Stripes", "id": "7073"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://www.stripes.com/polopoly_fs/1.483445.1503008428!/image/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/landscape_490/image.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 410, "textEnd": 417, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.stripes.com/news/pacific/navy-to-relieve-senior-uss-fitzgerald-leaders-of-duty-punish-others-in-fatal-crash-1.483444", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:12:00", "title": "Navy to relieve senior USS Fitzgerald leaders of duty, punish others in fatal crash", "uri": "711209087", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:11:00Z", "time": "22:11:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The U.S. Navy will relieve the USS Fitzgerald's top two officers and its senior enlisted sailor for issues connected to the warship's deadly collision with a cargo ship in June, the service's No. 2 admiral said Thursday.\n\nAdm. Bill Moran, the vice chief of Naval operations, said leadership aboard the guided-missile destroyer was at least partially at fault in the middle-of-the night collision June 17 with the Philippine-flagged ACX Crystal that left seven sailors dead. The Navy's investigation into the crash about 64 miles southwest of Yokosuka Naval Base is continuing and the service has yet to determine whether the cargo ship was also at fault, he said.\n\nVice Adm. Joseph P. Aucoin, the commander of 7th Fleet, is expected Friday to officially remove from duty the Fitzgerald's commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; its executive officer, Cmdr. Cmdr. Sean Babbits; and its command master chief, Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, Moran said. He did not provide specifics about their infractions, citing the ongoing investigation.\n\n\"We've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions,\" he said Thursday at the Pentagon. \"... When we lose confidence in someone - in their ability to lead - we hold them accountable.\"\n\nBenson, who was asleep inside his quarters when the Crystal's bow burst through its external wall, was injured in the crash. The Navy announced last month he had been temporarily removed from duty for his injuries. Moran said Thursday that he never returned to duty.\n\nBenson and about a dozen sailors on watch duty during the collision will face nonjudicial punishment at Captain's Mast on Friday, Moran said. Nonjudicial punishment includes a range of disciplinary actions that can cripple a career.\n\n\"When you look at what happened here, it's going to be hard to recover,\" Moran said.\n\nHe did not rule out additional punishments or the potential for courts-martial once the investigation is complete.\n\nA Navy investigation into the incident released Thursday shows that the 1:30 a.m. collision blasted a 17-by-13-foot hole into the side of the ship. One of the Fitzgerald's berthings, where 35 sailors were sleeping, flooded within 90 seconds.\n\nJolted awake by the crash, sailors rushed to check on their shipmates, taking actions that investigating officer Rear Adm. C.F. Williams determined likely saved the lives of at least two sailors.\n\nHowever, seven sailors inside the berthing perished, all drowning, according to the report. Those sailors were Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T. Truong Huynh, 25; Gunner's Mate 2nd Class Noe Hernandez, 26; Fire Controlman 2nd Class Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23; Personnel Specialist 1st Class Xavier Alec Martin, 24, and Firecontrolman 1st Class Gary Leo Rehm Jr., 37.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dead of the night to save their ship,\" Williams wrote. \"Ultimately, those damage control efforts and restoration processes succeeded in safely bringing Fitzgerald into port under her own power.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100, "id": {"sim": 0.6941176652908325, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9881023", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "sentinelsource.com", "title": "SentinelSource.com", "id": "2466"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/sentinelsource.com/content/tncms/custom/image/ce3b1b48-2e8a-11e7-9b31-dbe46a2a163d.jpg?_dc=1493655936", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 678, "textEnd": 685, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.sentinelsource.com/mcclatchy/navy-fires-top-two-officers-of-us-destroyer-for-collision/article_431f29c1-0f86-5b74-944d-39416fe16b14.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:24:00", "title": "Navy fires top two officers of US destroyer for collision that killed seven sailors", "uri": "711409122", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T11:24:00Z", "time": "11:24:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The commander and executive officer of a U.S. Navy destroyer were relieved from command as punishment for a collision with a container ship off Japan that killed seven sailors in June, one of the worst naval accidents in years, the Navy said Thursday.\n\nCmdr. Bryce Benson, commander of the Fitzgerald, and Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, the ship's second-in-command, were fired from their positions because the Navy \"lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" Adm. William F. Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters.\n\nThe pair were among about a dozen sailors on the destroyer, including the top enlisted sailor, who could face discipline for the June 17 collision with the Philippine-flagged merchant vessel ACX Crystal about 50 nautical miles southwest of the Japanese port of Yokosuka.\n\nIt's still unclear why the two huge ships didn't see and avoid each other -- that is subject to another investigation -- given modern radar and other sophisticated tracking marine gear, especially on the warship.\n\nBut the Navy said Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, had enough information to assign punishments for the collision.\n\nSeas were calm and the pre-dawn sky was still dark with scattered clouds when the ACX Crystal, which is 728 feet long and weighs 29,000 tons, suddenly smashed into the Fitzgerald, which is 505 feet long and 9,000 tons.\n\nThe crash carved a 13-by-17-foot gash into the Fitzgerald's forward starboard side above and below the water line. Water quickly flooded a large room where 42 sailors lay asleep in their berths, as well as a machinery space and the radio room.\n\nSeconds after impact, sailors jolted awake in Berthing 2 yelled \"water on deck\" and \"get out,\" according to a 41-page report on the deadly incident released by the Navy.\n\nBut seawater poured in so fast that it was already waist deep before the 42 sailors first tried to climb out. Thirty-five survived; seven did not.\n\nSaving the ship and getting it back to Yokosuka, home to the 7th Fleet, took unusual efforts, the report said,\n\n\"Through their swift and, in many cases, heroic actions, members of the Fitzgerald crew saved lives,\" the report said.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation.\"\n\nThe Japanese Coast Guard sent vessels to assist in rescue efforts while Japanese helicopters and a U.S. patrol aircraft flew near the destroyer.\n\nThree sailors required medical evacuation, including Benson, the ship's commander.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": While the container ship sustained little damage, the destroyer suffered severe damage to its starboard side.\n\nSeveral American and Japanese investigations took place into how the USS Fitzgerald and the container ship collided in clear weather south of Tokyo Bay.\n\nAccording to a copy of Captain Ronald Advincula's report to Japanese ship owner Dainichi Investment Corporation, the vessel had signaled with flashing lights after the warship \"suddenly\" steamed on to a course to cross its path.\n\nThe vessel attempted to get out of the path of the Fitzgerald, but hit it about 10 minutes later at 1:30 a.m., according to the report.\n\nMoran said the disciplinary moves are all \"initial accountability actions,\" which means the sailors could face more punishments depending on the outcome of different ongoing investigations.\n\n\"I'm not telling they will or they won't. It's just we are not done with the investigation,\" Moran said.\n\nFollowing the incident, the Navy's 7th Fleet commander said the collision \"could have been much worse.\"\n\n\"The crew's response was swift and effective, and I want to point out -- as we stand by the ship -- how proud I am of them,\" Vice Admiral Joseph Aucoin said.\n\n\"Heroic efforts prevented the flooding from catastrophically spreading, which could have caused the ship to founder or sink,\" Aucoin added. \"It could have been much worse.\"\n\nThe seven missing sailors from the USS Fitzgerald were found dead {"sim": 0.6901960968971252, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9796785", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "centralmaine.com", "title": "Central Maine", "id": "8208"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://multifiles.pressherald.com/uploads/sites/2/2017/08/1242153_Navy_Fitzgerald_Collision_5.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 67, "textEnd": 80, "date": "2017-06-17", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 288, "textEnd": 295, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.centralmaine.com/2017/08/17/top-officers-to-be-disciplined-for-deadly-collision-of-uss-fitzgerald/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:53:00", "title": "Top officers to be disciplined for deadly collision of USS Fitzgerald - CentralMaine.com", "uri": "711170163", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:53:00Z", "time": "23:53:00", "body": "The damaged USS Fitzgerald near the U.S. Naval base in Yokosuka on June 17, 2017. Associated Press\n\nThe top two officers and the top enlisted sailor who were aboard the destroyer USS Fitzgerald are among about a dozen sailors who will face discipline following an early-morning collision June 17 that killed seven crew members, a senior Navy officer said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters at the Pentagon that the majority of the punishments will be delivered Friday where the ship is homeported in Yokosuka, Japan. One sailor received an undisclosed administrative punishment Thursday.\n\nThe discipline will include likely career-ending actions against Cmdr. Bryce Benson, the ship's captain at the time, and his second in command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, Moran said. They and the senior enlisted sailor for the ship, Command Master Chief Brice Baldwin, will be removed as leaders of the ship permanently, Moran said.\n\nThe admiral said that sailors who were supposed to be on watch in the ship's bridge - its nerve center - also will be disciplined. Neither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal.\n\nThe container ship's bulbous nose ripped a 13-foot by 17-foot hole in the starboard size of the Fitzgerald, flooding one compartment where 35 sailors were inside within 90 seconds, Moran said. The ensuing flooding left disoriented sailors scrambling for their lives amid a soupy mix of personal items, electronics and mattresses, and some of the survivors were forced to seal a door with other sailors still inside in an effort to prevent the ship from sinking.\n\nhttps://cloudup.com/crVNrtifo6R\n\n\"You can just imagine the confusion and how difficult it would have been to escape Berthing Compartment 2,\" Moran said.\n\nBenson's stateroom also was flattened by the collision, injuring him and leaving him incapacitated. He was eventually medically evacuated from the Fitzgerald by a Japanese helicopter.\n\nThe sailors killed included Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T. Truong Huynh, 25; Gunner's Mate 2nd Class Noe Hernandez, 26; Fire Controlman 2nd Class Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23; Personnel Specialist 1st Class Xavier Alec Martin, 24, and Firecontrolman 1st Class Gary Leo Rehm Jr., 37.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? Associated Press\n\nThe top two officers and the top enlisted sailor who were aboard the destroyer USS Fitzgerald are among about a dozen sailors who will face discipline following an early-morning collision June 17 that killed seven crew members, a senior Navy officer said Thursday.\n\nAdm. William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters at the Pentagon that the majority of the punishments will be delivered Friday where the ship is homeported in Yokosuka, Japan. One sailor received an undisclosed administrative punishment Thursday.\n\nThe discipline will include likely career-ending actions against Cmdr. Bryce Benson, the ship's captain at the time, and his second in command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, Moran said. They and the senior enlisted sailor for the ship, Command Master Chief Brice Baldwin, will be removed as leaders of the ship permanently, Moran said.\n\nThe admiral said that sailors who were supposed to be on watch in the ship's bridge - its nerve center - also will be disciplined. Neither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal.\n\nThe container ship's bulbous nose ripped a 13-foot by 17-foot hole in the starboard size of the Fitzgerald, flooding one compartment where 35 sailors were inside within 90 seconds, Moran said. The ensuing flooding left disoriented sailors scrambling for their lives amid a soupy mix of personal items, electronics and mattresses, and some of the survivors were forced to seal a door with other sailors still inside in an effort to prevent the ship from sinking.\n\n\"You can just imagine the confusion and how difficult it would have been to escape Berthing Compartment 2,\" Moran said.\n\nBenson's stateroom also was flattened by the collision, injuring him and leaving him incapacitated. He was eventually medically evacuated from the Fitzgerald by a Japanese helicopter.\n\nThe sailors killed included Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T. Truong Huynh, 25; Gunner's Mate 2nd Class Noe Hernandez, 26; Fire Controlman 2nd Class Carlos Victor Ganzon Sibayan, 23; Personnel Specialist 1st Class Xavier Alec Martin, 24, and Firecontrolman 1st Class Gary Leo Rehm Jr., 37.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? {"sim": 0.6784313917160034, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9846850", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dw.com", "title": "Deutsche Welle (English)", "id": "430"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.dw.com/image/39295797_304.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1322, "textEnd": 1329, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/us-navy-fires-commanders-over-deadly-collision/a-40144626", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:58:00", "title": "US Navy fires commanders over deadly collision | News | DW | 18.08.2017", "uri": "711321031", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T07:58:00Z", "time": "07:58:00", "body": "Seven sailors were killed when the USS Fitzgerald struck a Philippine container ship in June. The Navy has blamed \"inadequate leadership\" for the crash.\n\nThe US Navy relieved several senior commanders of duty late Thursday over a deadly collision with a commercial container ship in June. The USS Fitzgerald struck the Philippine vessel off the coast of Japan, resulting in the death of seven US sailors.\n\nFortunately, no one aboard the ACX Crystal container ship was killed.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" said the Navy's 7th Fleet in a statement, adding that \"flawed\" teamwork also led to the deadly crash.\n\nCommanders Bryce Benson and Sean Babbitt, along with Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin have all been stripped of their duties, and more than a dozen other sailors will be punished for their conduct.\n\nThe Navy said that the trio had shown \"inadequate leadership,\" but that it could not release specific details as the investigation into the accident was ongoing.\n\nAccording to Admiral William Moran, vice chief of naval operations, the team responsible for keeping watch on the ship's bridge had \"lost situational awareness,\" leaving them unprepared to respond in time once the container ship was spotted.\n\nThe crash occurred during the early morning hours of June 17, when the bow of the ACX Crystal smashed into the USS Fitzgerald's right side, flooding one of the birthing areas. Twenty-eight of the soldiers sleeping in the cabin were able to escape and were later rescued, but seven drowned as water flooded the area without 30 to 60 seconds of the collision.\n\nThe Japanese Navy, which aided in rescue operations, is conducting its own investigation separate from the US inquiry.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": "country", {"sim": 0.6745098233222961, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9792473", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailypress.com", "title": "dailypress.com", "id": "4214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-599621af/turbine/dp-nws-fitzgerald-accident-report-20170817", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1099, "textEnd": 1106, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailypress.com/news/military/dp-nws-fitzgerald-accident-report-20170817-story.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:11:00", "title": "Collision at sea: Navy issues harrowing report on USS Fitzgerald", "uri": "711157568", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:11:00Z", "time": "23:11:00", "body": "A few sailors on the USS Fitzgerald heard a loud noise. Others were thrown from their beds. Then came shouts.\n\n\"Water on deck!\"\n\n\"Get out!\"\n\nIt was 1:30 a.m. off the coast of Japan, and the sea was pouring unimpeded into a berthing area of the guided-missile destroyer . A cargo ship had struck its starboard (right) side, ripping a 220-square-foot hole that spanned the second and third decks.\n\nIn seconds, mattresses, furniture, an exercise bike and wall lockers began floating in the aisles. As the initial shock wore off and training kicked in, sailors moved away from the onrushing water and calmly formed a line to leave the space via a port-side ladder.\n\nAs the last few sailors reached the ladder, water rose to their necks. The last sailor swam toward a light, breathing in water before being pulled to safety. A second sailor managed to escape via the starboard side, closer to the damaged hull. He found himself completely submerged, then discovered an air pocket. He doesn't remember how he escaped before collapsing on the deck.\n\nThese are among the details in a new Navy report of the June 17 collision between the Fitzgerald and the cargo ship ACX Crystal.\n\nSeven sailors died in the tragedy, including Chief Petty Officer Gary L. Rehm Jr., 37, who lived in Hampton and was buried Wednesday at Arlington National Cemetery.\n\nThe report credits Rehm by name for pushing a sailor out from under a fallen locker as the crew fought to escape.\n\nThe partially redacted report focuses on what happened after the collision. Separate investigations are ongoing into what led to the tragedy.\n\nA cover letter signed by Rear Adm. Charles Williams praises the sailors of Berthing 2. They fought back against initial shock and calmly formed lines to leave the damaged area, he said. Two sailors helped their buddies up the ladder, then climbed to the top and reached back into the water, hoping to find others.\n\n\"The crew of the Fitzgerald fought hard in the dark of night to save their ship,\" Williams wrote. \"Through their swift and, in many cases, heroic actions, members of the Fitzgerald crew saved lives.\"\n\nHowever, the collision was so severe that no damage-control measures \"would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation.\"\n\nCalm seas, then disaster\n\nThe Fitzgerald was operating about 56 nautical miles southwest of Yokosuka, Japan, near the Izu Peninsula when the collision happened. Seas were \"relatively calm,\" the report notes. There was scattered cloud cover and unrestricted visibility.\n\nThe collision occurred as the ACX Crystal struck the starboard side of the Fitzgerald with its bulbous bow, below the waterline. The force of the impact bent a wall to a nearly 90-degree angle.\n\n\"As a result, nothing separated Berthing 2 from the onrushing sea, allowing a great volume of water to enter Berthing 2 very quickly,\" the report states.\n\nThe ship listed 14 degrees to port, then settled into a 7-degree starboard list as the sea rushed in from that side.\n\nBerthing 2 is a crew area with 42 racks, or beds. It includes its own shower and bathroom space, plus a lounge with sofas, tables, chairs and a television. Sailors sleep in racks stacked three high. Of the 42 sailors assigned to Berthing 2, five were on watch and two were not aboard. Of the remaining 35, 28 were able to escape.\n\nSailors interviewed for the report had varying reactions after the collision. Some heard the noise. Others felt the ship move. Still others didn't realize what happened and remained in their racks. As the space began to flood, the report praises the sailors for being calm under pressure.\n\n\"Even though the sailors were up to their neck in water by that point, they moved forward slowly and assisted each other,\" the report states.\n\nTwo sailors stayed at the bottom of the ladder to help their buddies. They eventually had to escape themselves, but continued to search \"reaching into the dark water to find anyone they could.\"\n\nFrom the top of the ladder, these two sailors pulled two other sailors from the flooded compartment, the report states.\n\nTwo close calls\n\nThe report details the experiences of two sailors who almost didn't make it.\n\nOne who escaped from the port side was in a bathroom when the collision happened. A flood of water knocked him to the floor. At one point, a locker pinned him against the ceiling. He reached for a pipe and pulled himself free.\n\n\"He was swimming towards the watertight scuttle (a smaller opening on a hatch) when he was pulled from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported that when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water,\" the report states.\n\nOne sailor escaped the berthing compartment via the starboard side, closer to the damage and the onrushing sea. He moved against incoming water and floating furniture and heard someone say, \"Go, go, go it's blocked.\" But he was already underwater. After taking a few breaths in an air pocket, he swam. He doesn't remember how he escaped, but eventually escaped Berthing 2 before collapsing on the main deck. He was the only sailor to get out via the starboard side.\n\nCommander found hanging from ship\n\nThe Crystal's bow struck the cabin of the ship's commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson. Trapped inside, he called the bridge for help.\n\nFive sailors broke into the cabin using a sledgehammer, kettle bell and their bodies, the report states.\n\n\"The skin of the ship and outer bulkhead were gone and the night sky could be seen through the hanging wires and ripped steel,\" the report states. \"The rescue team tied themselves together with a belt in order to create a makeshift harness as they retrieved the CO, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\"\n\nBenson had to be medically evacuated. He has since been temporarily relieved of command due to medical reasons, according to reports.\n\nAs damage control efforts continued, reports of missing sailors began coming in. At 2:25 a.m., two sailors were unaccounted for. At 3:16 a.m., four sailors were missing.\n\nAt 5:40 a.m., a final all-hands muster determined that seven sailors were missing.\n\nTheir bodies were not recovered until the Fitzgerald limped back to Yokosuka Naval Base with the help of other ships. At 5:45 a.m the following day, divers entered Berthing 2 and immediately recovered one sailor. The six others followed.\n\nThe ship's command master chief identified the bodies.\n\n\"We continue to care for both the ship and her crew as they begin the rebuilding process,\" Williams' letter states. \"No one could have foreseen the challenges Fitzgerald would face, but the courage and strength shown by her crew, even as they mourn the loss of seven shipmates, underscore the essence of the Navy's core values.\"\n\nClick here to read the redacted report from the Navy. \"\n\nLessig can be reached by phone at 757-247-7821.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": destroyer, proceeded south from her homeport of Yokosuka, Japan at 20 knots in the early morning hours of June 17, more ships appeared and the area became \"congested,\" Moran said.\n\nThe USS Fitzgerald was involved in a collision with a cargo ship resulting in the deaths of seven Navy sailors aboard, all from the same berthing compartment, which flooded in about 90 seconds, Moran said.\n\n\"Clearly at some point the bridge team lost situational awareness,\" said Moran, describing the group of officers and sailors responsible for driving the warship through the water.\n\nIn addition to relieving the warship's top leadership, Moran said about a dozen other sailors also face disciplinary action.\n\nThey will face non-judicial punishments yet to be determined.\n\nAn {"sim": 0.6549019813537598, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9808452", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "latimes.com", "title": "Los Angeles Times", "id": "971"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-599649e0/turbine/la-na-essential-washington-updates-navy-fires-two-officers-of-destroyer-1503012966", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 85, "textEnd": 98, "date": "2017-08-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1480, "textEnd": 1487, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-navy-fires-two-officers-of-destroyer-1503012966-htmlstory.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:05:00", "title": "Navy fires top two officers of U.S. destroyer for collision that killed seven sailors", "uri": "711207401", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:05:00Z", "time": "02:05:00", "body": "Trump redoubles support for Confederate memorials and opposition to two GOP senators Aug. 17, 2017, 6:57 p.m.\n\nHere's our look at the Trump administration and the rest of Washington:\n\nThe president lauds GOP rival to Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake and attacks South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham Trump laments the removal of Confederate monuments as a loss to history and cultureWhite House strategist Stephen K. Bannon unloads in an unsolicited call to a liberal writerPresident Trump plans Arizona rally, his first in the West, but a mayor says don't come All updates Congress Economy Immigration Media Watch: On the Right North Korea Obamacare Russia White House Aug. 17, 2017, 6:57 p.m. Reporting from Washington Navy fires top two officers of U.S. destroyer for collision that killed seven sailors W.J. Hennigan\n\nThe commander and executive officer of a U.S. naval destroyer were relieved from command as punishment for a collision with a container ship off Japan that killed seven sailors in June, one of the worst naval accidents in years, the Navy announced Thursday.\n\nCmdr. Bryce Benson, commander of the Fitzgerald, and Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, the ship's second-in-command, were fired from their positions because the Navy \"lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead,\" Adm. William F. Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters.\n\nThe pair were among about a dozen sailors on the destroyer, including the top enlisted sailor, who could face discipline for the June 17 collision with the Philippine-flagged merchant vessel ACX Crystal about 50 nautical miles southwest of the Japanese port of Yokosuka.\n\nIt's still unclear why the two huge ships didn't see and avoid each other -- that is subject to another investigation -- given modern radar and other sophisticated tracking marine gear, especially on the warship.\n\nBut the Navy said Vice Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, had enough information to assign punishments for the collision.\n\nSeas were calm and the pre-dawn sky was still dark with scattered clouds when the ACX Crystal, which is 728 feet long and weighs 29,000 tons, suddenly smashed into the Fitzgerald, which is 505 feet long and 9,000 tons.\n\nThe crash carved a 13-by-17-foot gash into the Fitzgerald's forward starboard side above and below the water line. Water quickly flooded a large room where 42 sailors lay asleep in their berths, as well as a machinery space and the radio room.\n\nSeconds after impact, sailors jolted awake in Berthing 2 yelled \"water on deck\" and \"get out,\" according to a 41-page report on the deadly incident released by the Navy.\n\nBut seawater poured in so fast that it was already waist deep before the 42 sailors first tried to climb out. Thirty-five survived; seven did not.\n\nSaving the ship and getting it back to Yokosuka, home to the 7th Fleet, took unusual efforts, the report said,\n\n\"Through their swift and, in many cases, heroic actions, members of the Fitzgerald crew saved lives,\" the report said.\n\n\"No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation.\"\n\nThe Japanese Coast Guard sent vessels to assist in rescue efforts while Japanese helicopters and a U.S. patrol aircraft flew near the destroyer.\n\nThree sailors required medical evacuation, including Benson, the ship's commander.\n\nLatest updates Copyright \u00a9 2017, Los Angeles Times", "date": William F. Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters at the Pentagon that the majority of the punishments will be delivered Friday where the ship is homeported in Yokosuka, Japan. One sailor received an undisclosed administrative punishment Thursday.\n\nThe discipline will include likely career-ending actions against Cmdr. Bryce Benson, the ship's captain at the time, and his second in command, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, Moran said. They and the senior enlisted sailor for the ship, Command Master Chief Brice A. Baldwin, will be removed as leaders of the ship permanently, Moran said.\n\nThe admiral said that sailors who were supposed to be on watch in the ship's bridge -- its nerve center -- also will be disciplined. Neither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal.\n\nThe sailors killed included Gunner's Mate Seaman Dakota Kyle Rigsby, 19; Yeoman 3rd Class Shingo Alexander Douglass, 25; Sonar Technician 3rd Class Ngoc T. {"sim": 0.6470588445663452, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9883377", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "title": "NPR.org", "id": "78"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2017/08/18/fitz-170617-n-xn177-155_wide-5b773bdb5290e285dc5d5baef7946a65474cfa75.jpg?s=1400", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 408, "textEnd": 415, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/18/544387493/uss-fitzgerald-leaders-punished-crew-is-praised-after-collision-with-cargo-ship", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:37:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald Leaders Punished; Crew Is Praised After Collision With Cargo Ship", "uri": "711414862", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T11:37:00Z", "time": "11:37:00", "body": "The guided-missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald returns to port after colliding with a merchant vessel while operating southwest of Yokosuka, Japan.\n\nThe U.S. Navy has relieved the USS Fitzgerald's commander and two other senior leaders of their duties -- and it's also praising the crew for saving their ship after the destroyer collided with a large Philippine-flagged container ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"It was also evident from this review that the entire Fitzgerald crew demonstrated real toughness that night,\" the Navy said. \"Following the collision these Sailors responded with urgency, determination and creativity to save their ship.\"\n\nInadequate leadership and flawed teamwork contributed to the crash, the Navy said after releasing the findings of its investigation into the crash. It also blamed poor seamanship by the crews of both the guided-missile cruiser and the ACX Crystal, whose gross tonnage was triple that of the U.S. ship.\n\nSeven members of the Fitzgerald's crew died in the collision, which bashed in a large section of the ship above the waterline and caused extensive damage below. Water poured in through a large gash near its keel -- a 13-ft. by 17-ft. opening that was made by the cargo ship's bulbous bow -- as sailors responded to a collision that struck around 1:30 a.m.\n\n\"Through their swift and in many cases heroic actions, members of the crew saved lives,\" the Navy said. The report found that the sailors responded to flooding, structural damage and reports of a fire as they worked to restore the ship's power, propulsion and guidance.\n\nThe damage spanned two decks, and water poured into the ship -- particularly into Berthing 2, which held 42 beds and a lounge for the crew. By the time one sailor jumped from his top bunk, the water was chest high, the Navy says.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2, when the ship was struck, 28 escaped the flooding, and seven sailors died. The area flooded in a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\n\nHere's how the report describes one sailor's escape:\n\nThe ship's commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, was trapped in his cabin, which was hit by the Crystal's bow. After sailors used \"a sledgehammer, kettlebell, and their bodies\" to break through the door, the amount of debris forced them to remove the door's hinges to pry it open enough for a person to squeeze through.\n\nThose who entered could see night sky, looking through an opening of ripped steel and shredded wires, according to the report.\n\nA helicopter was later used to take Benson to a naval hospital in Japan. After the crash, the Fitzgerald switched over to using paper navigation charts due to a loss of its systems.\n\nThe damage limited the Fitzgerald's maximum speed to 5 knots and gave the ship a 5-degree starboard list. After it arrived in port, divers recovered the bodies of seven crew members.\n\nBenson had already been temporarily relieved of his duties due to injuries he suffered in the crash. He's now being reassigned to the Navy Yard in Washington, D.C., where the Navy says he'll be able to receive medical care.\n\nSeveral junior officers were also relieved of their duties, the Navy said.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime"}, {"sim": 0.6431372761726379, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9798151", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "title": "The Boston Globe", "id": "512"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://www.bostonglobe.com/rf/image_585w/Boston/2011-2020/2017/08/17/BostonGlobe.com/National/Images/AFP_PN7C0[1].jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/08/17/senior-officer-damaged-ship-relieved-command/ufcP0v9RbkOvnxCISLsG4K/story.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:08:00", "title": "Senior officer on damaged ship to be relieved of command - The Boston Globe", "uri": "711174400", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:08:00Z", "time": "00:08:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Navy plans to relieve the two top officers and the senior enlisted sailor of a destroyer that collided with a freighter off the coast of Japan in June, killing seven sailors in one of the sea service's deadliest accidents in years.\n\nThe head of the Navy's 7th Fleet, Vice Adm. Joseph P. Aucoin, was expected to take the action on Friday in Japan, the vice chief of naval operations, Adm. Bill Moran, told reporters on Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAbout a dozen sailors overall face career-killing administrative actions as a result of the accident, Moran said at a briefing at the Pentagon.\n\nA preliminary report into the accident released by the Navy on Thursday describes in harrowing detail the immediate aftermath of the collision and the rescue efforts aboard the USS Fitzgerald. The ship's routine cruise through familiar, if crowded seas, ended in the most deadly Navy accident in years.\n\nGet Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here\n\nDozens of sailors rocked from their slumber raced against time to escape up a ladder from their flooding quarters. The rushing water was at first waist high, then neck high as sailors pushed aside mattresses, wall lockers and other floating debris to clamber up a ladder to safety. The last sailor pulled from the chaos was underwater when his shipmates yanked him up.\n\nThe freighter crashed directly into the stateroom of the ship's captain, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, ripping open a huge hole and trapping him inside. Five sailors with a sledgehammer and kettlebell broke down the door to his cabin to rescue Benson, who was hanging from the side of the ship.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 319, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Services"}], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Japan"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Japan"}, "type": "loc", "id": "113"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "303092", "label": {"eng": "The Pentagon"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ship", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "id": "303600", "label": {"eng": "Ship"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destroyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "id": "304140", "label": {"eng": "Destroyer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sailor", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "306147", "label": {"eng": "Sailor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "306965", "label": {"eng": "Sea"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy", "type": "org", "score": 5, "id": "310233", "label": {"eng": "United States Navy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Seventh_Fleet", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "512234", "label": {"eng": "United States Seventh Fleet"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_Chief_of_Naval_Operations", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "846385", "label": {"eng": "Vice Chief of Naval Operations"}}]}

William Moran, the vice chief of naval operations, told reporters Thursday that the top three leaders aboard the USS Fitzgerald, which was badly damaged in the collision off the coast of Japan, will be removed from duty aboard the ship. They are the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson; the executive officer, Cmdr. Sean Babbitt; and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin, who as the ship's command master chief is its most senior enlisted sailor.\n\n\"The collision was avoidable, and both ships demonstrated poor seamanship,\" the Navy's 7th Fleet said in a statement, noting that \"flawed\" teamwork among those assigned to keep watch contributed to the collision.\n\nThe actions are being taken by Rear Adm. Joseph Aucoin, commander of the 7th Fleet, based at Yokosuka, Japan, because he lost confidence in the three, Moran said.\n\nThe Navy said the three had shown \"inadequate leadership.\" Separately, seven junior officers were relieved of their duties because they had shown \"poor seamanship\" and bad teamwork, 7th Fleet spokesman Cmdr. {"sim": 0.6392157077789307, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9808981", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "title": "Washington Examiner", "id": "2955"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://cdn.washingtonexaminer.biz/cache/1060x600-c63d55172f1f1719f03029d05b7491bb.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 285, "textEnd": 292, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/navy-to-relieve-uss-fitzgerald-commanders-details-heroic-efforts-of-crew-after-deadly-collision/article/2631910", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:12:00", "title": "Navy to relieve USS Fitzgerald commanders, details heroic efforts of crew after deadly collision", "uri": "711209049", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:11:00Z", "time": "21:11:00", "body": "The Navy is set to relieve the two top officers and the senior enlisted sailor of the USS Fitzgerald, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, Executive Officer Cmdr. Sean Babbitt, and Master Chief Petty Officer Brice Baldwin for failure to avoid a collision with a freighter in the early morning hours of June 17 off the coast of Japan.\n\nAll three will face career-ending administrative reprimand, called non-judicial punishment, in one of the Navy's deadliest accidents at sea in years, the Navy announced Thursday.\n\nAn official Navy investigation of the deadly collision between the destroyer USS Fitzgerald and a commercial container ship in June features a vivid description of the heroic efforts of the crew to save fellow sailors and the ship itself as ocean water gushed through the punctured hull.\n\nThe investigation focused on the action of the crew in response to the accident, not the events leading up to the collision, but as many as a dozen sailors could face career-ending letters of reprimand as a result of the accident.\n\nBut the investigation concludes the seven sailors who died did so in the line of duty and not due to misconduct or any failing on the part of fellow sailors, many of whom were asleep when the commercial container ship ACX Crystal rammed the destroyer, opening a huge gash in the starboard hull and flooding the berthing area.\n\n\"The Sailors assigned to Berthing 2 should be commended for their response to the dangerous and deadly threat they faced,\" the report said. \"Through their swift and, in many cases, heroic actions, members of the FITZGERALD crew saved lives. No damage control efforts, however, would have prevented Berthing 2 from flooding completely within the first two minutes following the collision, or the deadly circumstances in that situation.\"\n\nThe 43-page report is filled with harrowing accounts of last-minute escapes, and extraordinary efforts to save sailors who were trapped by rising water, or caught in the twisted wreckage.\n\nOf the ship's 300 member crew, 34 were trapped in the area that was flooded when the bulbous bow of the container ship cut a 13-by-17-foot hole in the side of the Fitzgerald.\n\nOf those 27 were able to escape, in some cases only because of the efforts of sailors operating under great emotional and physical stress.\n\nThe ship's command officer was sleeping in a part of the ship that took a direct hit, his cabin located just above the waterline.\n\n\"Five Sailors used a sledgehammer, kettlebell, and their bodies to break through the door into the CO's cabin, remove the hinges, and then pry the door open enough to squeeze through,\" the report recounts.\n\n\"A junior officer and two chief petty officers removed debris from in front of the door and crawled into the cabin. The skin of the ship and outer bulkhead were gone and the night sky could be seen through the hanging wires and ripped steel. The rescue team tied themselves together with a belt in order to create a makeshift harness as they retrieved the CO, who was hanging from the side of the ship.\"\n\nThe official investigation is filled with dramatic accounts of similar determination to save as many of the crew as possible, all while avoiding any signs of panic.\n\n\"They did what is expected of Sailors in such a situation: they checked racks to ensure everyone was awake; they formed calm lines to egress the space on the port side, away from the flooding; and they filed out of the Berthing in an orderly fashion, assisting one another to the ladder,\" the report concluded.\n\nIn one instance, two sailors who had been helping others from the bottom of a ladder were eventually forced to climb the ladder as water reached the very top of the compartment.\n\nBefore climbing the ladder, they checked and could not did not see any other sailors, but once they made it to the top, they reached back into the dark water and were able to pull two other sailors from the flooded compartment. Both were completely underwater when they were pulled to safety.\n\nThe report, based on interviews with the crew, was written in a style that eschewed the usual official jargon, and painted a dramatic picture of suspense, such as the account of sailor who was caught in the bathroom, when the waters flooded his compartment.\n\n\"Lockers were floating past him and he scrambled across them towards the main berthing area. At one point, he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free. He made his way to the only light he could see, which was coming from the port side watertight scuttle. He was swimming towards the watertight scuttle when he was pulled from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported that when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nOr the story of the sailor who jumped out of his rack into water that was chest deep and rising.\n\n\"He moved through the lounge furniture and against the incoming sea. Someone said, 'Go, go, go, it's blocked,' but he was already underwater. He was losing his breath under the water but found a small pocket of air. After a few breaths in the small air pocket, he eventually took one final breath and swam. He lost consciousness at this time and does not remember how he escaped from Berthing 2, but he ultimately emerged from the flooding into Berthing 1, where he could stand to his feet and breathe.\"\n\nThe full report, which is officially known as Supplemental Preliminary Inquiry and Line of Duty Determination, can be read below.\n\nA separate investigation into the cause of the accident, and the failure of the U.S. warship to take evasive action, is still underway.\n\nThe report does note that seas were \"relatively calm at 2 to 4 feet,\" \"the moon was relatively bright,\" with \"scattered cloud cover and unrestricted visibility\" at the time of the collision.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Environment/Water_Resources", "wgt": 100, "id": The Fitzgerald sailed into the path of the much larger container ship in the middle of the night, suffering heavy damage.\n\nThe report details the harrowing moments after impact, as sailors' sleeping quarters quickly filled with water. As dazed sailors clamored through water that was almost immediately waist deep, they were forced to navigate heavy floating debris to reach a ladder. The last sailor to escape was in water over his head when his fellow crew hauled him up the escape hatch.\n\n\"Two sailors chose to remain at the bottom of the ladder ... in order to help others out of the space, even as the water was rising and began flooding the space around them,\" the report states. \"The choices made by these two sailors likely saved the lives of at least two of their shipmates.\"\n\nTwo minutes after impact, the sleeping berth they were evacuating had completely filled with water.\n\nThe container ship, which suffered minimal damage, struck the Fitzgerald directly on the captain's sleeping quarters. The report details a dramatic rescue of Cmdr. Bryce Benson, after five junior crew members used sledgehammers to knock in the blocked door. When they finally got inside, Benson was hanging out a gaping hole in the side of the ship. They tied their belts together to create a makeshift harness and the ship's captain to safety.\n\nIn all, The New York Times reported 12 sailors, including the two top officers aboard and the top enlisted sailor, will face administrative actions that will likely end their careers after an investigation revealed the collision was the result of poor navigation practices by the Fitzgerald, and not the shipping container the Crystal. Those announcements were expected to come Friday at the U.S. naval base in Japan where the Fitzgerald now rests.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Maritime", "wgt": 100, "id": 288, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Maritime"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/History/By_Topic", "wgt": 100, "id": 653, "label": "dmoz/Society/History/By Topic"}], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Japan"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Japan"}, "type": "loc", "id": "113"}, {"location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asia", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Asia"}, "type": "loc", "id": "303540"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ship", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "id": "303600", "label": {"eng": "Ship"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times", "type": "org", "score": 2, "id": "303936", "label": {"eng": "The New York Times"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destroyer", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "id": "304140", "label": {"eng": "Destroyer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sailor", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "306147", "label": {"eng": "Sailor"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Container_ship", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "id": "313125", "label": {"eng": "Container ship"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Press_International", "type": "org", "score": 1, "id": "315021", "label": {"eng": "United Press International"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freight_transport", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "id": "323645", "label": {"eng": "Freight transport"}}]}

The duo, and the five other victims, were posthumously promoted on Wednesday.\n\nThe report focuses on the immediate aftermath of the collision and paints a harrowing account of the conditions faced by 35 sailors who had been asleep at the time.\n\n\"The occupants of Berthing 2 described a rapidly flooding space, estimating later that the space was nearly flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds,\" according to the 41-page report, which estimated the sailors had no more than 90 seconds to escape.\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep,\" the report said. \"Debris, including mattresses, furniture, an exercise bicycle, and wall lockers, floated into the aisles between racks in Berthing 2.\"\n\nThe ladder by which the sailors escaped was on the port side, and water quickly climbed to their necks. The seven who didn't survive were in starboard racks, and the only one who escaped by taking a route on that side went unconscious for a time and wasn't sure how he got out.\n\nNavy officials who wrote the report praised the heroism of the sailors in the damaged portion of the ship for helping their crewmates. At least two lives were saved by sailors who stayed in the area to provide assistance, the report noted.\n\nThe Fitzgerald's combat information center and commanding officer's quarters, which were above the waterline, were also heavily damaged by the container ship's bow.\n\nA combat systems officer and his roommate were injured, and the commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, was also injured and needed to be rescued.\n\nThe Navy on Thursday announced plans to relieve Benson, his executive officer and master chief for mistakes that led to the deadly collision.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Japan"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"sim": 0.6274510025978088, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370370", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9885486", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "publicradiotulsa.org", "title": "publicradiotulsa.org", "id": "3701"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3370370", "image": "http://mediad.publicbroadcasting.net/p/shared/npr/styles/medium/nprshared/201708/544388596.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 262, "textEnd": 269, "date": "-06-17", "amb": false}], "url": "http://publicradiotulsa.org/post/uss-fitzgerald-leaders-punished-crew-praised-after-collision-cargo-ship", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:52:00", "title": "USS Fitzgerald Leaders Punished; Crew Is Praised After Collision With Cargo Ship", "uri": "711420789", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T11:52:00Z", "time": "11:52:00", "body": "The U.S. Navy has relieved the USS Fitzgerald's commander and two other senior leaders of their duties -- and it's also praising the crew for saving their ship after the destroyer collided with a large Philippine-flagged container ship off the coast of Japan on June 17.\n\n\"It was also evident from this review that the entire Fitzgerald crew demonstrated real toughness that night,\" the Navy said. \"Following the collision these Sailors responded with urgency, determination and creativity to save their ship.\"\n\nInadequate leadership and flawed teamwork contributed to the crash, the Navy said after releasing the findings of its investigation into the crash. It also blamed poor seamanship by the crews of both the guided-missile cruiser and the ACX Crystal, whose gross tonnage was triple that of the U.S. ship.\n\nSeven members of the Fitzgerald's crew died in the collision, which bashed in a large section of the ship above the waterline and caused extensive damage below. Water poured in through a large gash near its keel -- a 13-ft. by 17-ft. opening that was made by the cargo ship's bulbous bow -- as sailors responded to an emergency around 1:30 a.m.\n\n\"Through their swift and in many cases heroic actions, members of the crew saved lives,\" the Navy said. The report found that the sailors responded to flooding, structural damage and reports of a fire as they worked to restore the ship's power, propulsion and guidance.\n\nThe damage spanned two decks, and water poured into the ship -- particularly into Berthing 2, which held 42 beds and a lounge for the crew. By the time one sailor jumped from his top bunk, the water was chest high, the Navy says.\n\nOf the 35 sailors who were in Berthing 2, when the ship was struck, 28 escaped the flooding, and seven sailors died. The area flooded in a span of 30 to 60 seconds.\n\nHere's how the report describes one sailor's escape:\n\n\"The last Sailor to be pulled from Berthing 2 was in the bathroom at the time of the collision and a flood of water knocked him to the deck (floor). Lockers were floating past him and he scrambled across them towards the main berthing area. At one point he was pinned between the lockers and the ceiling of Berthing 2, but was able to reach for a pipe in the ceiling to pull himself free. He made his way to the only light he could see, which was coming from the port side watertight scuttle. He was swimming towards the watertight scuttle when he was pulled from the water, red-faced and with bloodshot eyes. He reported that when taking his final breath before being saved, he was already submerged and breathed in water.\"\n\nThe ship's commanding officer, Cmdr. Bryce Benson, was trapped in his cabin, which was hit by the Crystal's bow. After sailors used \"a sledgehammer, kettlebell, and their bodies\" to break through the door, the amount of debris forced them to remove the door's hinges to pry it open enough for a person to squeeze through.\n\nThose who entered could see night sky, looking through an opening of ripped steel and shredded wires, according to the report.\n\nA helicopter was later used to take Benson to a naval hospital in Japan. After the crash, the Fitzgerald switched over to using paper navigation charts due to a loss of its systems.\n\nThe damage limited the Fitzgerald's maximum speed to 5 knots and gave the ship a 5-degree starboard list. After it arrived in port, divers recovered the bodies of seven crew members.\n\nBenson had already been temporarily relieved of his duties due to injuries he suffered in the crash. He's now being reassigned to the Navy Yard in Washington, D.C., where the Navy says he'll be able to receive medical care.\n\nSeveral junior officers were also relieved of their duties, the Navy Bill Moran told reporters August 17 at the Pentagon the Navy is not releasing the cost estimate publicly for what it will take \"to lift, not tow\" the ship to the United States.\n\n\"They will be detached from the ship for cause, which is, we've lost trust and confidence in their ability to lead in those positions and they will not return to the ship\", Vice Chief of Naval Operations Adm. William Moran told reporters at the Pentagon late Thursday.\n\nNeither Benson nor Babbitt was in the bridge at the time of the collision, in which the 505-foot destroyer was struck off the coast of Japan by a much heavier container ship, the Philippine-flagged MV ACX Crystal. Of the 35 sailors in the sleeping area at the time of the collision, 28 were able to escape, but the remaining seven sailors died.\n\nAccording to the initial reports, the Fitzgerald's crew did not take action needed to avoid the collision.\n\n\"The occupants of Berthing 2 described a rapidly flooding space, estimating later that the space was almost flooded within a span of 30 to 60 seconds\", according to the 41-page report, which estimated the sailors had no more than 90 seconds to escape.\n\nIt details the frantic efforts to account for all the sailors in the darkened, flooding compartment, keep the ship afloat, and rescue the ship's commander who dangled outside his crumpled cabin.\n\nBecause the investigation is ongoing, he could not say if the Fitzgerald was \"solely responsible\" for the collision with the ACX Crystal. One sailor received an undisclosed administrative punishment Thursday. \"Get out\", they shouted as mattresses, furniture and even an exercise bicycle began to float. Sailors staying in that area estimate the space flooded within 30 to 60 seconds.\n\nThe report confirms one sailor said Rehm pushed him out from under a falling locker.\n\nThe Navy's investigation into the crash about 64 miles southwest of Yokosuka Naval Base is continuing and the service has yet to determine whether the cargo ship was also at fault, he said.\n\n\"By the time the third sailor to leave arrived at the ladder, the water was already waist deep\", the report said.\n\nTwo minutes after impact, the sleeping berth they were evacuating had completely filled with water.\n\nThe final sailor pulled to safety had inhaled water and was pulled from the water \"red-faced\" with \"bloodshot eyes\".\n\nRelated News: 18 August 2017 Husband of missing SA woman found dead 18 August 2017
